custom_item_1.description: GEN000300 - All accounts on the system must have unique user or account names.
custom_item_1.info: A unique user name is the first part of the identification and authentication process.  If user names are not unique, there can be no accountability on the system for auditing purposes.  Multiple accounts sharing the same name could result in the denial of service to one or both of the accounts or unauthorized access to files or privileges.
custom_item_1.solution: Change user account names, or delete accounts, so each account has a unique name.
custom_item_1.name: passwd_duplicate_username

custom_item_2.description: GEN000320 - All accounts must be assigned unique User Identification Numbers (UIDs).
custom_item_2.info: Accounts sharing a UID have full access to each others' files.  This has the same effect as sharing a login.  There is no way to assure identification, authentication, and accountability because the system sees them as the same user. If the duplicate UID is 0, this gives potential intruders another privileged account to attack.
custom_item_2.solution: Edit user accounts to provide unique UIDs for each account.
custom_item_2.name: passwd_duplicate_uid

custom_item_3.description: GEN000380 - All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
custom_item_3.info: If a user is assigned the GID of a group not existing on the system, and a group with the GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to the group.
custom_item_3.solution: Add a group to the system for each GID referenced without a corresponding group.
custom_item_3.name: passwd_invalid_gid

custom_item_6.description: GEN000880 - The root account must be the only account having a UID of 0.
custom_item_6.info: If an account has a UID of 0, it has root authority. Multiple accounts with a UID of 0 afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.
custom_item_6.solution: Remove or change the UID of accounts other than root that have UID 0.
custom_item_6.name: passwd_zero_uid

custom_item_7.description: GEN000940 - The root accounts executable search path must contain only authorized paths.
custom_item_7.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Entries starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_7.solution:
Edit the root user's local initialization files ~/.profile,~/.bashrc (assuming root shell is bash).

Remove any empty path entries.

Remove any relative path entries that have not been documented with the ISSO.
custom_item_7.name: dot_in_root_path_variable

custom_item_8.description: GEN000960 - The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.
custom_item_8.info: If the root search path contains a world-writable directory, malicious software could be placed in the path by intruders and/or malicious users and inadvertently run by root with all of root's privileges.
custom_item_8.solution:
For each world-writable path in root's executable search path, do one of the following:

1. Remove the world-writable permission on the directory.
Procedure:
# chmod o-w2. Remove the world-writable directory from the executable search path.
Procedure:
Identify and edit the initialization file referencing the world-writable directory and remove it from the PATH variable.
custom_item_8.name: writeable_dirs_in_root_path_variable

custom_item_9.description: GEN000980 - The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.
custom_item_9.info: Limiting the root account direct logins to only system consoles protects the root account from direct unauthorized access from a non-console device.
custom_item_9.solution:
Create if needed and set the contents of /etc/securetty to a 'console' or 'tty' device.
# echo console > /etc/securetty
or
# echo tty1 > /etc/securetty
custom_item_9.name: root_login_from_console

custom_item_10.description: GEN001440 - All interactive users must be assigned a home directory in the /etc/passwd file.
custom_item_10.info: If users do not have a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they own.
custom_item_10.solution: Assign a home directory to any user without one.
custom_item_10.name: accounts_without_home_dir

custom_item_11.description: GEN001460 - All interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.
custom_item_11.info: If a user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given the / directory, by default, as the current working directory upon logon.  This could create a Denial of Service because the user would not be able to perform useful tasks in this location.
custom_item_11.solution:
If a user has no home directory, determine why. If possible, delete accounts without a home directory. If the account is valid, then create the home directory using the appropriate system administration utility or manually.
For instance: mkdir directoryname; copy the skeleton files into the directory; chown accountname for the new directory and the skeleton files. Document all changes.
custom_item_11.name: accounts_without_home_dir

custom_item_12.description: GEN001470 - The /etc/passwd file must not contain password hashes.
custom_item_12.info: If password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.
custom_item_12.name: passwd_shadowed

custom_item_13.description: GEN001480 - All user home directories must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
custom_item_13.info: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user files.
custom_item_13.solution:
Change the mode of user home directories to 0750 or less permissive.

Procedure (example):
# chmod 0750Note: Application directories are allowed and may need 0755 permissions (or greater) for correct operation.
custom_item_13.name: accounts_bad_home_permissions

custom_item_14.description: GEN001500 - All interactive user home directories must be owned by their respective users.
custom_item_14.info: If users do not own their home directories, unauthorized users could access user files.
custom_item_14.solution:
Change the owner of a user's home directory to its assigned user.

Procedure:
# chown
custom_item_14.name: accounts_bad_home_permissions

custom_item_15.description: GEN001520 - All interactive user home directories must be group-owned by the home directory owner's primary group.
custom_item_15.info: If the Group Identifier (GID) of the home directory is not the same as the GID of the user, this would allow unauthorized access to files.
custom_item_15.solution:
Change the group-owner for user home directories to the primary group of the assigned user.

Procedure:
Find the primary group of the user (GID) which is the fourth field of the user entry in /etc/passwd.

# chgrpDocument all changes.
custom_item_15.name: accounts_bad_home_group_permissions

custom_item_16.description: GEN001860 - All local initialization files must be owned by the home directorys user or root.
custom_item_16.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_16.solution:
Change the ownership of the startup and login files in the user's directory to the user or root, as appropriate.

Examine each user's home directory and verify all filenames beginning with '.' are owned by the owner of the directory or root.

If they are not, use the chown command to change the owner to the user and research the reasons why the owners were not assigned as required.

Procedure:
# chown username .filename

Document all changes.
custom_item_16.name: home_dir_localization_files_user_check

custom_item_17.description: GEN001870 - Local initialization files must be group-owned by the user's primary group or root.
custom_item_17.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_17.solution:
Change the group-owner of the local initialization file to the user's primary group, or root.
# chgrpProcedure:
# FILES='.bashrc .bash_login .bash_logout .bash_profile .cshrc .kshrc .login .logout .profile .tcshrc .env .dtprofile .dispatch .emacs .exrc';
# for PWLINE in 'cut -d: -f4,6 /etc/passwd'; do HOMEDIR=$(echo ${PWLINE}|cut -d: -f2);GROUP=$(echo ${PWLINE} | cut -d: -f1);for INIFILE in $FILES;do MATCH=$(stat -c %g/%G:%n ${HOMEDIR}/${INIFILE} 2>null|egrep -c -v '${GROUP}');if [ $MATCH != 0 ] ; then chgrp ${GROUP} ${HOMEDIR}/${INIFILE};fi;done;done
custom_item_17.name: home_dir_localization_files_group_check

custom_item_18.description: GEN002060 - All .rhosts, .shosts, .netrc, or hosts.equiv files must be accessible by only root or the owner - User '.rhosts'
custom_item_18.info: If these files are accessible by users other than root or the owner, they could be used by a malicious user to set up a system compromise.
custom_item_18.solution:
Ensure the permission for these files is set to 600 or more restrictive and their owner is root or the same as the owner of the home directory in which they reside.

Procedure:
# chmod 600 /etc/hosts.equiv
# chmod 600 /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv
# chown root /etc/hosts.equiv
# chown root /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv

# find / -name .rhosts
# chmod 600 //.rhosts
# chown/.rhosts

# find / -name .shosts
# chmod 600/.shosts
# chown/.shosts

# find / -name .netrc
# chmod 600/.netrc
# chown/.netrc
custom_item_18.name: home_dir_localization_files_user_check

custom_item_19.description: GEN002060 - All .rhosts, .shosts, .netrc, or hosts.equiv files must be accessible by only root or the owner - Group '.rhosts'
custom_item_19.info: If these files are accessible by users other than root or the owner, they could be used by a malicious user to set up a system compromise.

# chown/.rhosts

# find / -name .shosts
# chmod 600/.shosts
# chown/.shosts

# find / -name .netrc
# chmod 600/.netrc
# chown/.netrc
custom_item_19.name: home_dir_localization_files_group_check

custom_item_24.description: GEN002140 - All shells referenced in /etc/passwd must be listed in the /etc/shells file, except any specified for preventing logins.
custom_item_24.info: their default shell to an unauthorized unsecure shell.
custom_item_24.solution:
Use the 'chsh' utility or edit the /etc/passwd file and correct the error by changing the default shell of the account in error to an acceptable shell name contained in the /etc/shells file.

Example:
# chsh -s /bin/bash testuser
custom_item_24.name: invalid_login_shells

custom_item_25.description: GEN002200 - All shell files must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_25.info: If shell files are owned by users other than root or bin, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.
custom_item_25.solution:
Change the ownership of the shell with incorrect ownership.
# chown root
custom_item_25.name: login_shells_bad_owner

custom_item_26.description: GEN002380 - The owner, group, mode, ACL, and location of files with the setuid bit set must be documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_26.info: All files with the setuid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the UID of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setuid is assigned to programs allowing reading and writing of files, or shell escapes. Only default vendor-supplied executables should have the setuid bit set.
custom_item_26.solution: Document the files with the suid bit set or unset the suid bit on the executable.
custom_item_26.name: find_suid_sgid_files

custom_item_27.description: GEN002440 - The owner, group-owner, mode, ACL and location of files with the 'sgid' bit set must be documented.
custom_item_27.info: All files with the setgid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the GID of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setgid is assigned to programs allowing reading and writing of files, or shell escapes.
custom_item_27.solution: Document the files with the sgid bit set or unset the sgid bit on the executable.
custom_item_27.name: find_suid_sgid_files

custom_item_28.description: GEN002480 - Public directories must be the only world-writable directories and must be located only in public directories - 'files'
custom_item_28.info: World-writable files and directories make it easy for a malicious user to place potentially compromising files on the system.  The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_28.solution:
Remove or change the mode for any world-writable file on the system not required to be world-writable.

Procedure:
# chmod o-wDocument all changes
custom_item_28.name: find_world_writeable_files

custom_item_29.description: GEN002480 - Public directories must be the only world-writable directories and must be located only in public directories - 'directories'
custom_item_29.info: World-writable files and directories make it easy for a malicious user to place potentially compromising files on the system.  The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_29.solution:
Remove or change the mode for any world-writable file on the system not required to be world-writable.

Procedure:
# chmod o-wDocument all changes
custom_item_29.name: find_world_writeable_directories

custom_item_36.description: GEN001160 - All files and directories must have a valid owner.
custom_item_36.info: Un-owned files and directories may be unintentionally inherited if a user is assigned the same UID as the UID of the un-owned files.
custom_item_36.solution: All directories and files (executable and data) will have an identifiable owner and group name. Either trace files to an authorized user, change the file's owner to root, or delete them. Determine the legitimate owner of the files and use the chown command to set the owner and group to the correct value. If the legitimate owner cannot be determined, change the owner to root (but make sure none of the changed files remain executable because they could be Trojan horses or other malicious code). Examine the files to determine their origin and the reason for their lack of an owner/group.
custom_item_36.name: find_orphan_files

custom_item_37.description: GEN001170 - All files and directories must have a valid group-owner.
custom_item_37.info: Files without a valid group owner may be unintentionally inherited if a group is assigned the same GID as the GID of the files without a valid group-owner.
custom_item_37.solution:
Change the group-owner for each file without a valid group-owner.
# chgrp avalidgroup /tmp/a-file-without-a-valid-group-owner
custom_item_37.name: find_orphan_files

custom_item_39.description: GEN000000-LNX001431 - The /etc/gshadow file must be owned by root.
custom_item_39.info: The /etc/gshadow file is critical to system security and must be owned by a privileged user.  The /etc/gshadow file contains a list of system groups and hashes for group passwords.
custom_item_39.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/gshadow file to root.
# chown root /etc/gshadow

custom_item_40.description: GEN000000-LNX001432 - The /etc/gshadow file must be group-owned by root.
custom_item_40.info: The /etc/gshadow file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.   The /etc/gshadow file contains a list of system groups and hashes for group passwords.
custom_item_40.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/gshadow file to root.
# chgrp root /etc/gshadow

custom_item_41.description: GEN000000-LNX001433 - The /etc/gshadow file must have mode 0400.
custom_item_41.info: The /etc/gshadow file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.   The /etc/gshadow file contains a list of system groups and hashes for group passwords.
custom_item_41.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/gshadow file to 0400 or less permissive.
# chmod 0400 /etc/gshadow

custom_item_42.description: GEN000000-LNX001434 - The /etc/gshadow file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_42.info: The /etc/gshadow file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.   The /etc/gshadow file contains a list of system groups and hashes for group passwords.
custom_item_42.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/gshadow

custom_item_43.description: GEN000000-LNX001476 - The /etc/gshadow file must not contain any group password hashes.
custom_item_43.info: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used.
custom_item_43.solution: Edit /etc/gshadow and change the password field to an exclamation point (!) to lock the group password.

custom_item_44.description: GEN000000-LNX00320 - The system must not have special privilege accounts, such as shutdown and halt - '/etc/passwd - shutdown'
custom_item_44.info: If special privilege accounts are compromised, the accounts could provide privileges to execute malicious commands on a system.
custom_item_44.solution: Remove any special privilege accounts, such as shutdown and halt, from the /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files using the 'userdel' or 'system-config-users' commands.

custom_item_45.description: GEN000000-LNX00320 - The system must not have special privilege accounts, such as shutdown and halt - '/etc/shadow - shutdown'
custom_item_45.info: If special privilege accounts are compromised, the accounts could provide privileges to execute malicious commands on a system.
custom_item_45.solution: Remove any special privilege accounts, such as shutdown and halt, from the /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files using the 'userdel' or 'system-config-users' commands.

custom_item_48.info: If special privilege accounts are compromised, the accounts could provide privileges to execute malicious commands on a system.

custom_item_49.description: GEN000000-LNX00320 - The system must not have special privilege accounts, such as shutdown and halt - '/etc/shadow - reboot'
custom_item_49.info: If special privilege accounts are compromised, the accounts could provide privileges to execute malicious commands on a system.

custom_item_50.description: GEN000000-LNX00360 - The X server must have the correct options enabled - ':0 /usr/bin/X:0'
custom_item_50.info: Without the correct options enabled, the Xwindows system would be less secure and there would be no screen timeout.
custom_item_50.solution:
Enable the following options: -audit (at level 4), -auth and -s with 15 minutes as the timeout value.

Procedure for gdm:
Edit /etc/gdm/custom.conf and add the following:
[server-Standard]
name=Standard server
command=/usr/bin/Xorg -br -audit 4 -s 15
chooser=false
handled=true
flexible=true
priority=0

Procedure for xinit:
Edit or create a .xserverrc file in the users home directory containing the startup script for xinit.
This script must have an exec line with at least these options:

exec /usr/bin/X -audit 4 -s 15 -auth&

Theis created using the 'xauth' command and is customarily located in the users home directory with the name '.Xauthority'.

custom_item_54.description: GEN000000-LNX00380 - An X server must have none of the following options enabled: -ac, -core (except for debugging), or -nolock - '-ac'
custom_item_54.info: These options will detract from the security of the Xwindows system.
custom_item_54.solution:
Disable the unwanted options:
Procedure:
For gdm:
Remove the -ac, -core and -nolock options by creating a 'command' entry in the /etc/gdm/custom.conf file with the options removed.

For Xwindows started by xinit:
Create or modify the .xserverrc script in the users home directory to remove the -ac, -core and -nolock options from the exec /usr/bin/X command.

custom_item_57.description: GEN000000-LNX00400 - The /etc/security/access.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_57.info: The /etc/access.conf file contains entries restricting access from the system console by authorized System Administrators.  If the file is owned by a user other than root, it could compromise the system.
custom_item_57.solution:
Follow the correct configuration parameters for access configuration file. Use the chown command to configure it properly.
(for example:
# chown root /etc/security/access.conf
 ).

custom_item_58.description: GEN000000-LNX00420 - The /etc/security/access.conf file must have a privileged group owner.
custom_item_58.info: Depending on the access restrictions of the /etc/access.conf file, if the group owner were not a privileged group, it could endanger system security.
custom_item_58.solution:
Use the chgrp command to ensure the group owner is root, sys, or bin.
(for example: # chgrp root /etc/security/access.conf).

custom_item_59.description: GEN000000-LNX00440 - The /etc/security/access.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_59.info: If the access permissions are more permissive than 0640, system security could be compromised.
custom_item_59.solution:
Use the chmod command to set the permissions to 0640.
(for example: # chmod 0640 /etc/security/access.conf).

custom_item_60.description: GEN000000-LNX00450 - The /etc/security/access.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_60.info: If the access permissions are more permissive than 0640, system security could be compromised.
custom_item_60.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/security/access.conf

custom_item_61.description: GEN000000-LNX00480 - The /etc/sysctl.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_61.info: The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot.  These settings can affect the system's security.
custom_item_61.solution:
Use the chown command to change the owner of /etc/sysctl.conf to root:
# chown root /etc/sysctl.conf

custom_item_62.description: GEN000000-LNX00500 - The /etc/sysctl.conf file must be group-owned by root.
custom_item_62.info: The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot.  These settings can affect the system's security.
custom_item_62.solution:
Use the chgrp command to change the group owner of /etc/sysctl.conf to root:
# chgrp root /etc/sysctl.conf

custom_item_63.description: GEN000000-LNX00520 - The /etc/sysctl.conf file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_63.info: The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot.  These settings can affect the system's security.
custom_item_63.solution:
Use the chmod command to change the mode of the /etc/sysctl.conf file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/sysctl.conf

custom_item_64.description: GEN000000-LNX00530 - The /etc/sysctl.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_64.info: The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot.  These settings can affect the system's security.
custom_item_64.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/sysctl.conf

custom_item_65.description: GEN000000-LNX00560 - The Linux NFS Server must not have the insecure file locking option.
custom_item_65.info: Insecure file locking could allow for sensitive data to be viewed or edited by an unauthorized user.
custom_item_65.solution:
Remove the 'insecure_locks' option from all NFS exports on the system.

Procedure:

Edit /etc/exports and remove all instances of the insecure_locks option.

Re-export the file systems to make the setting take effect.
# exportfs -a

custom_item_66.description: GEN000000-LNX00580 - The x86 CTRL-ALT-DELETE key sequence must be disabled.
custom_item_66.info: Undesirable reboots can occur if the CTRL-ALT-DELETE key sequence is not disabled.  Such reboots may cause a loss of data or loss of access to critical information.
custom_item_66.solution:
Ensure the CTRL-ALT-DELETE key sequence has been disabled and attempts to use the sequence are logged.
In the /etc/inittab file replace:
ca::ctrlaltdel:/sbin/shutdown -t3 -r now
with
ca:nil:ctrlaltdel:/usr/bin/logger -p security.info 'Ctrl-Alt-Del was pressed'

custom_item_67.description: GEN000000-LNX00600 - PAM must not grant sole access to admin privileges to the first user who logs into the console - 'console.perms'

custom_item_68.description: GEN000000-LNX00600 - PAM system must not grant sole access to admin privileges to the first user who logs into the console. (/etc/pam.d/*)

custom_item_69.description: GEN000000-LNX00620 - The /etc/securetty file must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
custom_item_69.info: The securetty file contains the list of terminals permitting direct root logins.  It must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_69.solution:
Change the group-owner of /etc/securetty to root, sys, or bin.
Example:
# chgrp root /etc/securetty

custom_item_70.description: GEN000000-LNX00640 - The /etc/securetty file must be owned by root.
custom_item_70.info: The securetty file contains the list of terminals permitting direct root logins.  It must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_70.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/securetty file to root.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/securetty

custom_item_71.description: GEN000000-LNX00660 - The /etc/securetty file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_71.info: The securetty file contains the list of terminals permitting direct root logins.  It must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_71.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/securetty file to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/securetty

custom_item_72.description: GEN000000-LNX00720 - Auditing must be enabled at boot by setting a kernel parameter.
custom_item_72.info: If auditing is enabled late in the boot process, the actions of startup scripts may not be audited. Some audit systems also maintain state information only available if auditing is enabled before a given process is created.
custom_item_72.solution:
Edit the grub bootloader file /boot/grub/grub.conf or /boot/grub/menu.lst by appending the 'audit=1' parameter to the kernel boot line.
Reboot the system for the change to take effect.

custom_item_73.description: GEN000000-LNX00800 - Use a Linux Security Module configured to limit the privileges of system services - 'SELINUX = enforcing'
custom_item_73.info: Linux Security Modules such as SELinux and AppArmor can be used to provide protection from software exploits by explicitly defining the privileges permitted to each software package.
custom_item_73.solution:
Enable one of the SELinux policies.
Edit /etc/sysconfig/selinux and set the value of the SELINUX option to 'enforcing' and SELINUXTYPE to 'targeted' or 'strict'.
Restart the system.

custom_item_74.description: GEN000000-LNX00800 - Use a Linux Security Module configured to limit privileges of system services - 'SELINUXTYPE = targeted or strict'
custom_item_74.info: Linux Security Modules such as SELinux and AppArmor can be used to provide protection from software exploits by explicitly defining the privileges permitted to each software package.
custom_item_74.solution:
Enable one of the SELinux policies.
Edit /etc/sysconfig/selinux and set the value of the SELINUX option to 'enforcing' and SELINUXTYPE to 'targeted' or 'strict'.
Restart the system.

custom_item_75.description: GEN000020 - The system must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
custom_item_75.info: If the system does not require valid root authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system.
custom_item_75.solution:
Edit /etc/inittab and set sulogin to run in single-user mode.
Example line in /etc/inittab:
~:S:wait:/sbin/sulogin

Note: The first field in the /etc/inittab line may be any sequence of 1-4 characters.

custom_item_76.description: GEN000100 - The operating system must be a supported release.
custom_item_76.info: An operating system release is considered 'supported' if the vendor continues to provide security patches for the product. With an unsupported release, it will not be possible to resolve security issues discovered in the system software.
custom_item_76.solution: Upgrade to a supported version of the operating system.

custom_item_77.description: GEN000140-2 - A file integrity baseline including cryptographic hashes must be created and maintained - '/etc/aide.conf must exist'
custom_item_77.info: A file integrity baseline is a collection of file metadata that is to evaluate the integrity of the system. A minimal baseline must contain metadata for all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal metadata must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files, metadata must also include file size and a cryptographic hash of the file's contents.
custom_item_77.solution:
Use AIDE to create a file integrity baseline, including cryptographic hashes, for the system.

Configure the /etc/aide.conf file to ensure some form of cryptographic hash (e.g., md5,rmd160,sha256) is used for files. In the default /etc/aide.conf the 'NORMAL' or 'LSPP' rules which are used for virtually all files DO include some form of cryptographic hash.

custom_item_80.description: GEN000140-3 - A file integrity baseline including cryptographic hashes must be maintained. - '/etc/aide.conf exists'
custom_item_80.info: A file integrity baseline is a collection of file metadata that is to evaluate the integrity of the system. A minimal baseline must contain metadata for all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal metadata must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files, metadata must also include file size and a cryptographic hash of the file's contents.
custom_item_80.solution:
Regularly rebuild the integrity baseline, including cryptographic hashes, for the system to be consistent with the latest approved system configuration.

Procedure:
After an approved modification to the system configuration has been made perform:

# aide -u
This will update the database.

custom_item_83.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - 'ntpd'
custom_item_83.name: ntpd

custom_item_84.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - 'xntpd'
custom_item_84.name: xntpd

custom_item_85.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - 'xntpd'

custom_item_86.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/var/spool/cron/'

custom_item_87.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/etc/cron.d/*'

custom_item_88.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/etc/cron.daily/*'

custom_item_89.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/etc/cron.hourly/*'

custom_item_90.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/etc/cron.monthly/*'

custom_item_91.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source - '/etc/cron.weekly/*'

custom_item_92.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source.
custom_item_92.info: To assure the accuracy of the system clock, it must be synchronized with an authoritative time source within DoD.  Many system functions, including time-based login and activity restrictions, automated reports, system logs, and audit records depend on an accurate system clock.  If there is no confidence in the correctness of the system clock, time-based functions may not operate as intended and records may be of diminished value.  Authoritative time sources include authorized time servers within the enclave that synchronize with upstream authoritative sources.  Specific requirements for the upstream synchronization of network time protocol (NTP) servers are covered in the Network Other Devices STIG.  For systems located on isolated or closed networks, it is not necessary to synchronize with a global authoritative time source.  If a global authoritative time source is not available to systems on an isolated network, a local authoritative time source must be established on this network and used by the systems connected to this network.  This is necessary to provide the ability to correlate events and allow for the correct operation of time-dependent protocols between systems on the isolated network.  If the system is completely isolated (i.e., it has no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events between systems will be necessary. If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_92.solution: Use an authoritative local time server or a time server operated by the U.S. government.  Ensure all systems in the facility feed from one or more local time servers which feed from the authoritative U.S. government time server.

custom_item_93.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - '/var/spool/cron/root'

custom_item_94.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - '/etc/crontab'

custom_item_95.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - '/etc/cron.d/*'

custom_item_96.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - '/etc/cron.daily/*'

custom_item_97.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - 'ntpd'
custom_item_97.name: ntpd

custom_item_98.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously - 'maxpoll 10'
custom_item_98.info:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. Internal system clocks tend to drift and require periodic resynchronization to ensure their accuracy. Software, such as ntpd, can be used to continuously synchronize the system clock with authoritative sources. Alternatively, the system may be synchronized periodically, with a maximum of one day between synchronizations.

If the system is completely isolated (i.e., it has no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary. If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_98.solution:
Enable the NTP daemon for continuous synchronization.
# service ntpd start ; chkconfig ntpd on

Edit the '/etc/ntp.conf' file and add or update an entry to define 'maxpoll' to '10'.

custom_item_99.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - '/var/spool/cron/root'

custom_item_100.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - '/etc/crontab'

custom_item_101.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - '/etc/cron.d/*'

custom_item_102.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - '/etc/cron.daily/*'

custom_item_103.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - '/etc/ntp.conf'
custom_item_103.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  For redundancy, two time sources are required so synchronization continues to function if one source fails.    If the system is completely isolated (i.e., it has no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary.  If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.  Note:  For the network time protocol (NTP), the requirement is two servers, but it is recommended to configure at least four distinct time servers which allow NTP to effectively exclude a time source not consistent with the others.  The system's local clock must be excluded from the count of time sources.
custom_item_103.solution:
If using 'ntpd -qg', add additional NTP servers to the cron job running 'ntpd -qg'.

If using the NTP daemon, add an additional 'server' line to /etc/ntp.conf for each additional NTP server.

custom_item_104.description: GEN000244 - The system must use time sources that are local to the enclave
custom_item_104.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  The network architecture should provide multiple time servers within an enclave providing local service to the enclave and synchronize with time sources outside of the enclave.  If this server is an enclave time server, this requirement is not applicable.  If the system is completely isolated (i.e., it has no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary.  If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_104.solution:
If using 'ntpd -qg', remove NTP servers external to the enclave from the cron job running 'ntpd -qg'.

If using the NTP daemon, remove the 'server' line from /etc/ntp.conf for each NTP server external to the enclave.

custom_item_105.description: GEN000250 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.
custom_item_105.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system account, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_105.solution:
Change the owner of the NTP configuration file.
# chown root /etc/ntp.conf

custom_item_106.description: GEN000251 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_106.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system group, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_106.solution:
Change the group-owner of the NTP configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/ntp.conf

custom_item_107.description: GEN000252 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_107.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_107.solution:
Change the mode of the NTP configuration file to 0640 or more restrictive.
# chmod 0640 /etc/ntp.conf

custom_item_108.description: GEN000253 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_108.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_108.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the NTP configuration file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/ntp.conf

custom_item_109.description: GEN000290-1 - The system must not have the unnecessary 'games' account.
custom_item_109.info: Accounts that provide no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.
custom_item_109.solution:
Remove the 'games' account.

Procedure:
# userdel games

custom_item_110.description: GEN000290-2 - The system must not have the unnecessary 'news' account.
custom_item_110.info: Accounts that provide no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.
custom_item_110.solution: Remove the 'news' account from the /etc/passwd file before connecting a system to the network.

custom_item_111.description: GEN000290-3 - The system must not have the unnecessary 'gopher' account.
custom_item_111.info: Accounts that provide no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.
custom_item_111.solution: Remove the 'gopher' account from the /etc/passwd file before connecting a system to the network.

custom_item_114.description: GEN000290-4 - The system must not have the unnecessary 'ftp' account.
custom_item_114.info: Accounts that provide no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.
custom_item_114.solution: Remove the 'ftp' account from the /etc/passwd file before connecting a system to the network.

custom_item_115.description: GEN000340 - UIDs reserved for system accounts must not be assigned to non-system accounts.
custom_item_115.info: Reserved UIDs are typically used by system software packages.  If non-system accounts have UIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the user having permissions to modify system files.
custom_item_115.solution: Change the UID numbers for non-system accounts with reserved UIDs (those less or equal to 499).

custom_item_116.description: GEN000360 - GIDs reserved for system accounts must not be assigned to non-system groups.
custom_item_116.info: Reserved GIDs are typically used by system software packages.  If non-system groups have GIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the group having permissions to modify system files.
custom_item_116.solution: Change the primary group GID numbers for non-system accounts with reserved primary group GIDs (those less or equal to 499).

custom_item_117.description: GEN000400 - The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.
custom_item_117.info: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.
custom_item_117.solution:
Edit /etc/issue and add one of the DoD login banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system).

DoD Login Banners:

You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests- -not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

OR

I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.

custom_item_118.description: GEN000410 - The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense login banner - '/etc/banners/vsftpd'
custom_item_118.info: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.  Note:  SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP to be used in place of FTP.  SFTP is implemented by the SSH service and uses its banner configuration.
custom_item_118.solution:
Provide the proper text for the DoD banner to be presented by the FTP server to the user.

For vsftp:
Examine the /etc/vsftp.conf file for the 'banner_file' entry. (i.e. banner_file = /etc/banner/vsftp)

For gssftp:
Examine the /etc/xinetd.d/gssftp file for the 'banner' entry. (i.e. banner = /etc/banner/gssftp)

For both:
Add the banner entry if one is not found.

Modify or create the referenced banner file to contain one of the following DoD login banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system).

DoD Login Banners:

You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

OR

custom_item_119.description: GEN000410 - The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense login banner - '/etc/xinetd.d/gssftp'
custom_item_119.info: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.  Note:  SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP to be used in place of FTP.  SFTP is implemented by the SSH service and uses its banner configuration.
custom_item_119.solution:
Provide the proper text for the DoD banner to be presented by the FTP server to the user.

For vsftp:
Examine the /etc/vsftp.conf file for the 'banner_file' entry. (i.e. banner_file = /etc/banner/vsftp)

For gssftp:
Examine the /etc/xinetd.d/gssftp file for the 'banner' entry. (i.e. banner = /etc/banner/gssftp)

For both:
Add the banner entry if one is not found.

Modify or create the referenced banner file to contain one of the following DoD login banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system).

DoD Login Banners:

You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

custom_item_120.description: GEN000440 - Successful and unsuccessful logins and logouts must be logged - '/var/log/wtmp'
custom_item_120.info: Monitoring and recording successful and unsuccessful logins assists in tracking unauthorized access to the system.  Without this logging, the ability to track unauthorized activity to specific user accounts may be diminished.
custom_item_120.solution:
Make sure the collection files exist.
Procedure:
If there are no successful logins being returned from the 'last' command, create /var/log/wtmp:
# touch /var/log/wtmp

If there are no unsuccessful logins being returned from the 'lastb' command, create /var/log/btmp:
# touch /var/log/btmp

custom_item_124.description: GEN000450 - System must limit users to 10 simultaneous system logins or a site-defined number in accordance with operational requirements

custom_item_125.description: GEN000450 - System must limit users to 10 simultaneous system logins or a site-defined number in accordance with operational requirements

custom_item_126.description: GEN000452 - The system must display the date and time of the last successful account login upon login - 'pam_lastlog.so'

custom_item_127.description: GEN000452 - The system must display the date and time of the last successful account login upon login - 'PrintLastLog'.

custom_item_128.description: GEN000460 - The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.

custom_item_129.description: GEN000480 - The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.
custom_item_129.info: Enforcing a delay between successive failed login attempts increases protection against automated password guessing attacks.
custom_item_129.solution:
Add the pam_faildelay module and set the FAIL_DELAY variable.

Procedure:

Edit /etc/login.defs and set the value of the FAIL_DELAY variable to 4 or more.

The default link /etc/pam.d/system-auth points to /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac which is the file maintained by the authconfig utility. In order to add pam options other than those available via the utility create or modify /etc/pam.d/system-auth-local with the options and including system-auth-ac. For example:

auth required pam_access.so
auth optional pam_faildelay.so delay=4000000
auth include system-auth-ac
account include system-auth-ac
password include system-auth-ac
session include system-auth-ac

Once system-auth-local is written ensure the /etc/pam.d/system-auth points to system-auth-local. This is necessary because authconfig writes directly to system-auth-ac so any manual changes made will be lost if authconfig is run.

custom_item_131.description: GEN000500 - The graphical desktop environment must have idle timeout enabled
custom_item_131.info: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.
custom_item_131.solution:
For the Gnome screen saver, set the idle_activation_enabled flag.
Procedure:
# gconftool-2 --direct --config-source xml:readwrite:/etc/gconf/gconf.xml.mandatory --type bool --set /apps/gnome-screensaver/idle_activation_enabled true

custom_item_133.description: GEN000500-2 - The graphical desktop environment must set the idle timeout to no more than 15 minutes.
custom_item_133.info: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.
custom_item_133.solution:
For the Gnome screen saver, set idle_delay to 15.

Procedure:
# gconftool-2 --direct --config-source xml:readwrite:/etc/gconf/gconf.xml.mandatory --type int --set /apps/gnome-screensaver/idle_delay 15

custom_item_134.description: GEN000500-3 - Graphical desktop environments provided by the system must have automatic lock enabled.
custom_item_134.info: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.
custom_item_134.solution:
For the Gnome screen saver, set the lock_enabled flag.

Procedure:
# gconftool-2 --direct --config-source xml:readwrite:/etc/gconf/gconf.xml.mandatory --type bool --set /apps/gnome-screensaver/lock_enabled true

custom_item_135.description: GEN000540 - Users must not be able to change passwords more than once every 24 hours.
custom_item_135.info: The ability to change passwords frequently facilitates users reusing the same password. This can result in users effectively never changing their passwords.  This would be accomplished by users changing their passwords when required and then immediately changing it to the original value.
custom_item_135.solution:
Change the minimum time period between password changes for each user account to 1 day.
# passwd -n 1

custom_item_136.description: GEN000560 - The system must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords - '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'

custom_item_137.description: GEN000560 - The system must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords - '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac'

custom_item_138.description: GEN000580 - The system must require passwords contain a minimum of 15 characters.
custom_item_138.info: The use of longer passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques by increasing the password search space.
custom_item_138.solution:
Edit "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" to include the line:
password required pam_cracklib.so minlen=15
prior to the "password include system-auth-ac" line.

Edit /etc/login.defs to include the line:

PASS_MIN_LEN	15

custom_item_139.description: GEN000585 - The system must enforce the correctness of the entire password during authentication - '/etc/passwd'
custom_item_139.info: Some common password hashing schemes only process the first eight characters of a user's password, which reduces the effective strength of the password.
custom_item_139.solution:
Change the passwords for all accounts using non-compliant password hashes.

(This requires GEN000590 is already met.)

custom_item_140.description: GEN000585 - The system must enforce the correctness of the entire password during authentication - '/etc/shadow'
custom_item_140.info: Some common password hashing schemes only process the first eight characters of a user's password, which reduces the effective strength of the password.
custom_item_140.solution:
Change the passwords for all accounts using non-compliant password hashes.

(This requires GEN000590 is already met.)

custom_item_141.description: GEN000590 - The system must use a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm for generating account password hashes.
custom_item_141.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.
custom_item_141.solution:
Change the default password algorithm.
# authconfig --passalgo=sha512 --update

NOTE: Executing the above command will also update the required parameters in /etc/login.defs and /etc/libuser.conf

custom_item_142.description: GEN000595 - The password hashes must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm - '/etc/passwd'
custom_item_142.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.
custom_item_142.solution: Change the passwords for all accounts using non-compliant password hashes.

custom_item_143.description: GEN000595 - The password hashes must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm - '/etc/shadow'
custom_item_143.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.
custom_item_143.solution: Change the passwords for all accounts using non-compliant password hashes.

custom_item_144.description: GEN000600 - The system must require that passwords contain at least one uppercase alphabetic character.
custom_item_144.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated. The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques. Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_144.solution:
Edit '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' to include the line:

password required pam_cracklib.so ucredit=-1

prior to the 'password include system-auth-ac' line.

custom_item_145.description: GEN000600-2 - Ensure global settings defined in system-auth are applied in the pam.d definition files - 'link != /etc/pam.d/system-auth'
custom_item_145.info: Pam global requirements are generally defined in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth or /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac file. In order for the requirements to be applied the file containing them must be included directly or indirectly in each program's definition file in /etc/pam.d
custom_item_145.solution: In the default distribution of RHEL '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' is a symlink '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac' which is an autogenerated file. When a site adds password requirements a new system-auth-local file must be created with only the additional requirements and includes for auth, account, passwd and session pointing to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac'. Then the symlink '/etc/system-auth' is modified to point to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-local'. This way any changes made do not get lost when '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac' is regenerated and each program's pam.d definition file need only have 'include system-auth' for auth, account, passwd and session, as needed, in order to assure the password requirements will be applied to it.

custom_item_146.description: GEN000600-2 - Ensure global settings defined in system-auth are applied in the pam.d definition files - 'link = system-auth-local'
custom_item_146.info: Pam global requirements are generally defined in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth or /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac file. In order for the requirements to be applied the file containing them must be included directly or indirectly in each program's definition file in /etc/pam.d
custom_item_146.solution: In the default distribution of RHEL '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' is a symlink '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac' which is an autogenerated file. When a site adds password requirements a new system-auth-local file must be created with only the additional requirements and includes for auth, account, passwd and session pointing to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac'. Then the symlink '/etc/system-auth' is modified to point to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-local'. This way any changes made do not get lost when '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac' is regenerated and each program's pam.d definition file need only have 'include system-auth' for auth, account, passwd and session, as needed, in order to assure the password requirements will be applied to it.

custom_item_147.info: Pam global requirements are generally defined in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth or /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac file. In order for the requirements to be applied the file containing them must be included directly or indirectly in each program's definition file in /etc/pam.d

custom_item_148.description: GEN000610 - The system must require that passwords contain at least one lowercase alphabetic character.
custom_item_148.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_148.solution:
Edit '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' to include the line:

prior to the 'password include system-auth-ac' line.

custom_item_149.description: GEN000620 - The system must require that passwords contain at least one numeric character.
custom_item_149.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_149.solution:
Edit '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' to include the line:

password required pam_cracklib.so dcredit=-1

prior to the 'password include system-auth-ac' line.

custom_item_150.description: GEN000640 - The system must require that passwords contain at least one special character.
custom_item_150.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_150.solution:

prior to the 'password include system-auth-ac' line.

custom_item_151.description: GEN000680 - The system must require that passwords contain no more than three consecutive repeating characters.
custom_item_151.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, the number of consecutive repeating characters is limited.  Passwords with excessive repeated characters may be more vulnerable to password-guessing attacks.
custom_item_151.solution:
Edit '/etc/pam.d/system-auth' to include the line:

password required pam_cracklib.so maxrepeat=3

prior to the 'password include system-auth-ac' line.

custom_item_152.description: GEN000700 - User passwords must be changed at least every 60 days.
custom_item_152.info: Limiting the lifespan of authenticators limits the period of time an unauthorized user has access to the system while using compromised credentials and reduces the period of time available for password-guessing attacks to run against a single password.
custom_item_152.solution:
Set the max days field to 60 for all user accounts.
# passwd -x 60

custom_item_153.description: GEN000750 - The system must require that at least eight characters be changed between the old and new passwords during a password change.
custom_item_153.info: To ensure password changes are effective in their goals, the system must ensure that old and new passwords have significant differences. Without significant changes, new passwords may be easily guessed based on the value of a previously compromised password.
custom_item_153.solution: If /etc/pam.d/system-auth references /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac refer to the man page for system-auth-ac for a description of how to add options not configurable with authconfig. Edit /etc/pam.d/system-auth and add or edit a pam_cracklib entry with an difok parameter set equal to or greater than 8.

custom_item_154.description: GEN000790 - The system must prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords.
custom_item_154.info: An easily guessable password provides an open door to any external or internal malicious intruder.  Many computer compromises occur as the result of account name and password guessing.  This is generally done by someone with an automated script that uses repeated logon attempts until the correct account and password pair is guessed.  Utilities, such as cracklib, can be used to validate passwords are not dictionary words and meet other criteria during password changes.
custom_item_154.solution: If /etc/pam.d/system-auth references /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac refer to the man page for system-auth-ac for a description of how to add options not configurable with authconfig. Edit /etc/pam.d/system-auth and configure pam_cracklib by adding a line such as 'password required pam_cracklib.so'

custom_item_155.description: GEN000800 - The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations - '/etc/security/opasswd'
custom_item_155.info: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.
custom_item_155.solution:
Create the password history file.
# touch /etc/security/opasswd
# chown root:root /etc/security/opasswd
# chmod 0600 /etc/security/opasswd

Enable password history.
If /etc/pam.d/system-auth references /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac refer to the man page for system-auth-ac for a description of how to add options not configurable with authconfig. Edit /etc/pam.d/system-auth to include the remember option on any 'password pam_unix' or 'password pam_history' lines set to at least 5.

custom_item_156.description: GEN000800 - The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations - '/etc/security/opasswd must exist'
custom_item_156.info: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.
custom_item_156.solution:
Create the password history file.
# touch /etc/security/opasswd
# chown root:root /etc/security/opasswd
# chmod 0600 /etc/security/opasswd

Enable password history.
If /etc/pam.d/system-auth references /etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac refer to the man page for system-auth-ac for a description of how to add options not configurable with authconfig. Edit /etc/pam.d/system-auth to include the remember option on any 'password pam_unix' or 'password pam_history' lines set to at least 5.

custom_item_157.description: GEN000800 - The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations - '/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac remember > 5'
custom_item_157.info: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.

Edit /etc/pam.d/system-auth to include the remember option on any 'password pam_unix' or 'password pam_history' lines set to at least 5.

custom_item_158.description: GEN000800 - The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations - '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
custom_item_158.info: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.

custom_item_159.description: GEN000850 - The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group.
custom_item_159.info: Configuring a supplemental group for users permitted to switch to the root user prevents unauthorized users from accessing the root account, even with knowledge of the root credentials.
custom_item_159.solution: Edit /etc/pam.d/su and uncomment or add a line such as 'auth required pam_wheel.so'. If necessary, create a 'wheel' group and add administrative users to the group.

custom_item_160.description: GEN000900 - The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).
custom_item_160.info: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other user home directories.
custom_item_160.solution:
The root home directory should be something other than / (such as /roothome).

Procedure:
# mkdir /rootdir
# chown root /rootdir
# chgrp root /rootdir
# chmod 700 /rootdir
# cp -r /.??* /rootdir/.

Then, edit the passwd file and change the root home directory to /rootdir. The cp -r /.??* command copies all files and subdirectories of file names beginning with '.' into the new root directory, which preserves the previous root environment. Ensure you are in the '/' directory when executing the 'cp' command.

custom_item_161.description: GEN000920 - The root account's home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
custom_item_161.info: Permissions greater than 0700 could allow unauthorized users access to the root home directory.
custom_item_161.solution:
The root home directory will be configured to have permission set of 0700 or less permissive. Do not change the protections of the / directory. Use the following command to change protections for the root home directory:
# chmod 0700 /rootdir.

custom_item_162.description: GEN000930 - The root account's home directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_162.info: The root account's home directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_162.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the root account's home directory.
# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_163.description: GEN000945 - The root account's library search path must be the system default and must contain only absolute paths.
custom_item_163.info: The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries.  If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries.  This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories.  If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory.  Entries starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_163.solution: Edit the root user initialization files and remove any definition of LD_LIBRARY_PATH.

custom_item_164.description: GEN000950 - The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.
custom_item_164.info: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary.  If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded.  This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries.  Paths starting with (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_164.solution: Edit the root user initialization files and remove any definition of LD_PRELOAD.

custom_item_165.description: GEN001000 - Remote consoles must be disabled or protected from unauthorized access.
custom_item_165.info: The remote console feature provides an additional means of access to the system which could allow unauthorized access if not disabled or properly secured.  With virtualization technologies, remote console access is essential as there is no physical console for virtual machines.  Remote console access must be protected in the same manner as any other remote privileged access method.
custom_item_165.solution:
Create if needed and set the contents of /etc/securetty to a 'console' or 'tty' device.
# echo console > /etc/securetty
or
# echo tty1 > /etc/securetty

custom_item_166.description: GEN001020 - The root account must not be used for direct logins.
custom_item_166.info: NOTE : It is possible that log files have rotated and traces of root login may not exist even if the activity has occurred.
custom_item_166.solution: Enforce policy requiring all root account access is attained by first logging into a user account and then becoming root preferably through the use of 'sudo' which provides traceability to the command level. If that is not workable then using 'su' to access the root account will provide traceability to the login user.

custom_item_167.description: GEN001025 - The sudo command must require authentication -/etc/sudoers - NOPASSWD
custom_item_167.info: The 'sudo' command allows authorized users to run programs (including shells) as other users, system users, and root. The '/etc/sudoers' file is used to configure authorized 'sudo' users as well as the programs they are allowed to run. Some configuration options in the '/etc/sudoers' file allow configured users to run programs without re-authenticating. Use of these configuration options makes it easier for one compromised account to be used to compromise other accounts.
custom_item_167.solution:
Update the '/etc/sudoers' or other sudo configuration files to remove or comment out lines utilizing the 'NOPASSWD' and '!authenticate' options.

# visudo
# visudo -f [other sudo configuration file]

custom_item_171.description: GEN001060 - The system must log successful and unsuccessful access to the root account - syslog 'authpriv.*'
custom_item_171.info: If successful and unsuccessful logins and logouts are not monitored or recorded, access attempts cannot be tracked. Without this logging, it may be impossible to track unauthorized access to the system.
custom_item_171.solution:
Troubleshoot the system logging configuration to provide for logging of root account login attempts.
Procedure:
Edit /etc/syslog.conf or /etc/rsyslog.conf to make sure 'authpriv.*' messages are directed to a file or remote system.
Examine /etc/audit/audit.rules to ensure user authentication messages have not been specifically excluded.
Remove any entries that correspond to:
-a exclude,never -Fmsgtype=USER_START
-a exclude,never -Fmsgtype=USER_LOGIN
-a exclude,never -Fmsgtype=USER_AUTH
-a exclude,never -Fmsgtype=USER_END
-a exclude,never -Fmsgtype=USER_ACCT
