custom_item_180.description: GEN001100 - Root passwords must never be passed over a network in clear text form - 'last'

custom_item_181.description: GEN001100 - Root passwords must never be passed over a network in clear text form - 'sshd'
custom_item_181.name: sshd

custom_item_182.description: GEN001120 - The system must not permit root logins using remote access programs such as ssh.
custom_item_182.info: Even though communications are encrypted, an additional layer of security may be gained by extending the policy of not logging directly on as root.  In addition, logging in with a user-specific account preserves the audit trail.
custom_item_182.solution: Edit the sshd_config file and set the PermitRootLogin option to 'no'.

custom_item_183.description: GEN001310 - All library files must not have extended ACLs - '/usr/lib/*'
custom_item_183.info: Unauthorized access could destroy the integrity of the library files.
custom_item_183.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /usr/lib/* /lib/*

custom_item_184.description: GEN001310 - All library files must not have extended ACLs - '/lib/*'

custom_item_187.description: GEN001320 - NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.
custom_item_187.info: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are critical to system security.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_187.solution:
Change the ownership of NIS/NIS+/yp files to root, sys or bin.
Procedure (example):
# chown root

custom_item_188.description: GEN001340 - NIS/NIS+/yp files must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
custom_item_188.info: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_188.solution:
Perform the following to change NIS file ownership.

# chgrp root /var/yp/*

custom_item_189.description: GEN001360 - The NIS/NIS+/yp command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_189.info: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are critical to system security.  Unauthorized modification of these files could compromise these processes and the system.
custom_item_189.solution:
Change the mode of NIS/NIS+/yp command files to 0755 or less permissive.

Procedure (example):
# chmod 0755

custom_item_190.description: GEN001361 - NIS/NIS+/yp command files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_190.info: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are critical to system security.  ACLs on these files could result in unauthorized modification, which could compromise these processes and the system.
custom_item_190.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /var/yp/*

custom_item_191.description: GEN001362 - The /etc/resolv.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_191.info: The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver.  DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses.  If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information.  DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.
custom_item_191.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/resolv.conf file to root.
# chown root /etc/resolv.conf

custom_item_192.description: GEN001363 - The /etc/resolv.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_192.info: The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver.  DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses.  If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information.  DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.
custom_item_192.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/resolv.conf file to root, bin, or sys.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/resolv.conf

custom_item_193.description: GEN001364 - The /etc/resolv.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.

custom_item_195.info: The /etc/hosts file (or equivalent) configures local host name to IP address mappings that typically take precedence over DNS resolution. custom_item_204.description: GEN001375 - For systems using DNS resolution, at least two name servers must be configured - first name server
custom_item_204.info: To provide availability for name resolution services, multiple redundant name servers are mandated. A failure in name resolution could lead to the failure of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.
custom_item_204.solution: Edit /etc/resolv.conf and add additional 'nameserver' lines until at least two are present.

custom_item_205.description: GEN001375 - For systems using DNS resolution, at least two name servers must be configured - second name server
custom_item_205.info: To provide availability for name resolution services, multiple redundant name servers are mandated. A failure in name resolution could lead to the failure of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.
custom_item_205.solution: Edit /etc/resolv.conf and add additional 'nameserver' lines until at least two are present.

custom_item_206.description: GEN001378 - The /etc/passwd file must be owned by root.
custom_item_206.info: The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts.  It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_206.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/passwd file to root.
# chown root /etc/passwd

custom_item_207.description: GEN001379 - The /etc/passwd file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_207.info: The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts.  It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_207.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/passwd file to root, bin or sys.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/passwd

custom_item_208.description: GEN001380 - The /etc/passwd file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_208.info: If the passwd file is writable by a group-owner or the world, the risk of passwd file compromise is increased.  The passwd file contains the list of accounts on the system and associated information.
custom_item_208.solution:
Change the mode of the passwd file to 0644.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644 /etc/passwd

custom_item_209.description: GEN001390 - The /etc/passwd file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_209.info: File system ACLs can provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_209.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/passwd

custom_item_210.description: GEN001391 - The /etc/group file must be owned by root.
custom_item_210.info: The /etc/group file is critical to system security and must be owned by a privileged user.  The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information.
custom_item_210.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/group file to root.
# chown root /etc/group

custom_item_211.description: GEN001392 - The /etc/group file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_211.info: The /etc/group file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information.
custom_item_211.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/group file.

Procedure:

custom_item_217.description: GEN001430 - The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must not have an extended ACL.

custom_item_218.description: GEN001475 - The /etc/group file must not contain any group password hashes.
custom_item_218.info: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used.  Additionally, if password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.
custom_item_218.solution: Edit /etc/group and change the password field to an exclamation point (!) to lock the group password.

custom_item_219.description: GEN001490 - User home directories must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_219.info: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user files.
custom_item_219.solution:

Document all changes.

custom_item_223.description: GEN001600 - Run control scripts' executable search paths must contain only absolute paths - '/etc/init.d/*'
custom_item_223.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_223.solution:
Edit the run control script and remove any relative path entries from the executable search path variable that are not documented with the ISSO.

Edit the run control script and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_232.description: GEN001660 - All system start-up files must be owned by root.
custom_item_232.info: System start-up files not owned by root could lead to system compromise by allowing malicious users or applications to modify them for unauthorized purposes.  This could lead to system and network compromise.
custom_item_232.solution:
Change the ownership of the run control script(s) with incorrect ownership.
# find /etc -name '[SK][0-9]*'|xargs stat -L -c %U:%n|egrep -v '^root:'|cut -d: -f2|xargs chown root

custom_item_233.description: GEN001680 - All system start-up files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, other, or system.
custom_item_233.info: If system start-up files do not have a group owner of root or a system group, the files may be modified by malicious users or intruders.
custom_item_233.solution:
Change the group ownership of the run control script(s) with incorrect group ownership.

Procedure:
# chgrp root# find /etc -name '[SK][0-9]*'|xargs stat -L -c %G:%n|egrep -v '^(root|sys|bin|other):'|cut -d: -f2|xargs chgrp root

custom_item_234.description: GEN001720 - All global initialization files must have mode 0644 or less permissive - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_234.info: Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_234.solution:
Change the mode of the global initialization file(s) to 0644.
# chmod 0644

custom_item_243.description: GEN001730 - All global initialization files must not have extended ACLs - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_243.info: Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_243.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.

# ls -l etc/bashrc /etc/csh.cshrc /etc/csh.login /etc/csh.logout /etc/environment /etc/ksh.kshrc /etc/profile /etc/suid_profile /etc/profile.d/* 2>null|grep '\+ '|sed 's/^.* \///g'|xargs setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_252.description: GEN001740 - All global initialization files must be owned by root - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_252.info: Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_252.solution:
Change the ownership of global initialization files with incorrect ownership.

Procedure:
# chown rootor:
# ls etc/bashrc /etc/csh.cshrc /etc/csh.login /etc/csh.logout /etc/environment /etc/ksh.kshrc /etc/profile /etc/suid_profile /etc/profile.d/* 2>null|xargs stat -L -c %U:%n|egrep -v '^root'|cut -d: -f2|xargs chown root
will set the owner of all files not currently owned by root to root.

# ls -lL /etc/bashrc /etc/csh.cshrc /etc/csh.login /etc/csh.logout /etc/environment /etc/ksh.kshrc /etc/profile /etc/suid_profile /etc/profile.d/* 2>null|sed 's/^[^\/]*//'|xargs stat -L -c %G:%n|egrep -v '^(root|sys|bin|other):'|cut -d: -f2|xargs chgrp root
will set the group of all files not currently owned by an approved group to root.

custom_item_263.description: GEN001760 - All global initialization files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, other, system, or the system default - '/etc/csh.login'
custom_item_263.info: Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_263.solution:
Change the group ownership of the global initialization file(s) with incorrect group ownership.

custom_item_270.description: GEN001780 - Global initialization files must contain the 'mesg -n' or 'mesg n' commands - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_270.info: If the 'mesg -n' or 'mesg n' command is not placed into the system profile, messaging can be used to cause a Denial of Service attack.
custom_item_270.solution: Edit /etc/profile or another global initialization script, and add the 'mesg -n' command.

custom_item_279.description: GEN001800 - All skeleton files (typically those in /etc/skel) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_279.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.
custom_item_279.solution:
Change the mode of skeleton files with incorrect mode:
# chmod 0644

custom_item_280.description: GEN001810 - Skeleton files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_280.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.
custom_item_280.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all [skeleton file with extended ACL]
or:
# ls -lL /etc/skel|grep '\+ '|sed 's/^.* \//|xargs setfacl --remove-all
will remove all ACLs from the files.

custom_item_281.description: GEN001820 - All skeleton files and directories (typically in /etc/skel) must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_281.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_281.solution:
Change the ownership of skeleton files with incorrect mode:
# chown rootor
# ls -L /etc/skel|xargs stat -L -c %U:%n|egrep -v '^(root|bin):'|cut -d: -f2|chown root
will change all files not owned by root or bin to root.

custom_item_282.description: GEN001830 - All skeleton files (typically in /etc/skel) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, system, or other.
custom_item_282.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.
custom_item_282.solution:
Change the group-owner of the skeleton file to root, bin, sys, system, or other.

Procedure:
# chgrp/etc/skel/[skeleton file]
or:
# ls -L /etc/skel|xargs stat -L -c %G:%n|egrep -v '^(root|bin|sy|sytem|other):'|cut -d: -f2|chgrp root
will change the group of all files not already one of the approved group to root.

custom_item_283.description: GEN001840 - All global initialization files executable search paths must contain only authorized paths - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_283.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_283.solution: Edit the global initialization file(s) with PATH variables containing relative paths and remove any relative path from the PATH variables that have not been authorized by the ISSO.  Edit the global initialization file(s) and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_301.description: GEN001850 - Global initialization files lists of preloaded libraries must contain only authorized paths - '/etc/bashrc'
custom_item_301.info: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded. This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries. custom_item_310.description: GEN001880 - All local initialization files must have mode 0740 or less permissive - '.bashrc'
custom_item_310.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_310.solution:
Ensure user startup files have permissions of 0740 or more restrictive. Examine each user's home directory and verify all file names beginning with '.' have access permissions of 0740 or more restrictive. If they do not, use the chmod command to correct the vulnerability.

Procedure:
# chmod 0740 .filename

Note: The period is part of the file name and is required.

custom_item_325.description: GEN001900 - All local initialization files executable search paths must contain only authorized paths.
custom_item_325.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_325.solution:
Edit the local initialization file and remove the relative path entry from the executable search path variable. If this is not feasible, justify and document the necessity of having the relative path for a specific application with the ISSO.

Edit the local initialization file and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_326.description: GEN001901 - Local initialization files library search paths must contain only authorized paths.
custom_item_326.info: The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_326.solution:
Edit the local initialization file and remove any relative path entries that have not been documented with the ISSO.

Edit the local initialization file and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_327.description: GEN001902 - Local initialization files lists of preloaded libraries must contain only authorized paths.

If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded. This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_327.solution:
Edit the local initialization file and remove any relative path entry from the library preload variable that has not been authorized by the ISSO.

Edit the local initialization file and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_328.description: GEN001980 - Files must not contain a plus (+) without defining entries for NIS+ netgroups - '.rhosts'
custom_item_328.info: A plus (+) in system accounts files causes the system to lookup the specified entry using NIS.  If the system is not using NIS, no such entries should exist.
custom_item_328.solution: Edit the .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, shosts.equiv, /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, and/or /etc/group files and remove entries containing a plus (+).

custom_item_335.description: GEN002000 - There must be no .netrc files on the system.
custom_item_335.info: Unencrypted passwords for remote FTP servers may be stored in .netrc files. Policy requires passwords be encrypted in storage and not used in access scripts.
custom_item_335.solution:
Remove the .netrc file(s).

Procedure:
# find / -name .netrc
# rm <.netrc file>

custom_item_336.description: GEN002040 - There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system - '.rhosts'
custom_item_336.info: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system.  Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.

custom_item_337.description: GEN002040 - There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system - '.shosts'
custom_item_337.info: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system.  Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.

custom_item_338.description: GEN002040 - There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system - 'hosts.equiv'
custom_item_338.info: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system.  Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.

custom_item_339.description: GEN002040 - There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system - 'shosts.equiv'
custom_item_339.info: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system.  Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.

custom_item_340.description: GEN002060 - All .rhosts, .shosts, .netrc, or hosts.equiv files must be accessible by only root or the owner - '/etc/hosts.equiv'
custom_item_340.info: If these files are accessible by users other than root or the owner, they could be used by a malicious user to set up a system compromise.
custom_item_340.solution:
Ensure the permission for these files is set to 600 or more restrictive and their owner is root or the same as the owner of the home directory in which they reside.

Procedure:
# chmod 600 /etc/hosts.equiv
# chmod 600 /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv
# chown root /etc/hosts.equiv
# chown root /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv

# find / -name .rhosts
# chmod 600 //.rhosts
# chown/.rhosts

# find / -name .shosts
# chmod 600/.shosts
# chown/.shosts

# find / -name .netrc
# chmod 600/.netrc
# chown/.netrc

custom_item_345.description: GEN002100 - The .rhosts file must not be supported in PAM.
custom_item_345.info: .rhosts files are used to specify a list of hosts permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating. The use of such a mechanism defeats strong identification and authentication requirements.
custom_item_345.solution: Edit the file(s) in /etc/pam.d referencing the rhosts_auth module, and remove the references to the rhosts_auth module.

custom_item_346.description: GEN002120 - The /etc/shells (or equivalent) file must exist.
custom_item_346.info: The shells file (or equivalent) lists approved default shells. It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized unsecure shell.
custom_item_346.solution:
Create a /etc/shells file containing a list of valid system shells. Consult vendor documentation for an appropriate list of system shells.

Procedure:
# echo '/bin/bash' >> /etc/shells
# echo '/bin/csh' >> /etc/shells
(Repeat as necessary for other shells.)

custom_item_347.description: GEN002210 - All shell files must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_347.info: If shell files are group-owned by users other than root or a system group, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.
custom_item_347.solution:
Change the group-owner of the shell to root, bin, sys, or system.

Procedure:
# chgrp root

custom_item_348.description: GEN002220 - All shell files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_348.info: Shells with world/group write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify the shell to obtain unauthorized access.
custom_item_348.solution:
Change the mode of the shell.
# chmod 0755

custom_item_349.description: GEN002230 - All shell files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_349.info: Shells with world/group write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify the shell to obtain unauthorized access.
custom_item_349.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all [shell]

custom_item_350.description: GEN002320 - Audio devices must have mode 0664 or less permissive - '/dev/audio*'
custom_item_350.info: Audio and video devices that are globally accessible have proven to be another security hazard.  There is software that can activate system microphones and video devices connected to user workstations and/or X terminals.  Once the microphone has been activated, it is possible to eavesdrop on otherwise private conversations without the victim being aware of it.  This action effectively changes the user's microphone into a bugging device.
custom_item_350.solution:
Change the mode of audio devices.
# chmod 0660

custom_item_351.description: GEN002320 - Audio devices must have mode 0664 or less permissive - '/dev/snd/*'

This action effectively changes the user's microphone into a bugging device.
custom_item_351.solution:
Change the mode of audio devices.
# chmod 0660

custom_item_352.description: GEN002330 - Audio devices must not have extended ACLs - '/dev/audio*'
custom_item_352.info: File system ACLs can provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.
custom_item_352.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all [device file]

custom_item_356.info: Without privileged group owners, audio devices will be vulnerable to being used as eaves-dropping devices by malicious users or intruders to possibly listen to conversations containing sensitive information.
custom_item_356.solution:
Change the group-owner of the audio device.

Procedure:

custom_item_358.description: GEN002420 - Removable media, remote file systems, and any file system that do not contain suid files must be mounted with 'nosuid' option.
custom_item_358.info: The 'nosuid' mount option causes the system to not execute setuid files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved setuid files. Executing setuid files from untrusted file systems, or file systems not containing approved setuid files, increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
custom_item_358.solution: Edit /etc/fstab and add the 'nosuid' mount option to all file systems mounted from removable media or network shares, and any file system not containing approved setuid or setgid files.

custom_item_359.description: GEN002430 - Removable media, remote file systems and any file system that do not contain device files must be mounted with 'nodev' option.
custom_item_359.info: The 'nodev' (or equivalent) mount option causes the system to not handle device files as system devices. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved device files. Device files can provide direct access to system hardware and can compromise security if not protected.
custom_item_359.solution: Edit /etc/fstab and add the 'nodev' option to any filesystems mounted from removable media or network shares.

custom_item_360.description: GEN002500 - The sticky bit must be set on all public directories.
custom_item_360.info: Failing to set the sticky bit on the public directories allows unauthorized users to delete files in the directory structure.  The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_360.solution:
Set the sticky bit on all public directories.

Procedure:
# chmod 1777 /tmp

(Replace /tmp with the public directory missing the sticky bit, if necessary.)

custom_item_361.description: GEN002520 - All public directories must be owned by root or an application account.
custom_item_361.info: If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not owned by a privileged UID, unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.  The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_361.solution:
Change the owner of public directories to root or an application account.

Procedure:
# chown root /tmp

(Replace root with an application user and/or /tmp with another public directory as necessary.)

custom_item_362.description: GEN002540 - All public directories must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.
custom_item_362.info: If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not group-owned by a privileged GID, unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.  The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_362.solution:
Change the group-ownership of the public directory.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /tmp

(Replace root with a different system group and/or /tmp with a different public directory as necessary.)

custom_item_363.description: GEN002560 - The system and user default umask must be 077 - '/etc/*'
custom_item_363.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0. This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.
custom_item_363.solution: Edit local and global initialization files that contain 'umask' and change them to use 077 instead of the current value.

custom_item_364.description: GEN002560 - The system and user default umask must be 077 - '~/.*'
custom_item_364.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0. This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.
custom_item_364.solution: Edit local and global initialization files that contain 'umask' and change them to use 077 instead of the current value.

custom_item_365.description: GEN002640 - Default system accounts must be disabled or removed - 'sys'
custom_item_365.info: Vendor accounts and software may contain backdoors allowing unauthorized access to the system. These backdoors are common knowledge and present a threat to system security if the account is not disabled.
custom_item_365.solution:

custom_item_371.info: Without auditing, individual system accesses cannot be tracked and malicious activity cannot be detected and traced back to an individual account.
custom_item_371.solution:
Start the auditd service and set it to start on boot.
# service auditd start ; chkconfig auditd on

custom_item_373.description: GEN002680 - System audit logs must be owned by root.
custom_item_373.info: Failure to give ownership of system audit log files to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information.
custom_item_373.solution:
Change the ownership of the audit log file(s).

Procedure:

custom_item_374.description: GEN002690 - System audit logs must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.

Procedure:
# chgrp root

custom_item_375.description: GEN002700 - System audit logs must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_375.info: If a user can write to the audit logs, audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected.  System audit logs are those files generated from the audit system and do not include activity, error, or other log files created by application software.
custom_item_375.solution:
Change the mode of the audit log directories/files.
# chmod 0750# chmod 0640

custom_item_376.description: GEN002710 - All system audit files must not have extended ACLs.

custom_item_376.solution: Remove the extended ACL from the system audit file(s).

custom_item_401.description: GEN002719 - The audit system must alert the SA in the event of an audit processing failure - '/etc/audit/auditd.conf disk_full_action'
custom_item_401.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity. If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event, and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as e-mail or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_401.solution: Edit /etc/audit/auditd.conf and set the disk_full_action and/or disk_error_action parameters to a valid setting of 'syslog', 'exec', 'single' or 'halt', adding the parameters if necessary.

custom_item_402.description: GEN002719 - The audit system must alert the SA in the event of an audit processing failure - '/etc/audit/auditd.conf disk_error_action'
custom_item_402.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity. If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event, and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as e-mail or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_402.solution: Edit /etc/audit/auditd.conf and set the disk_full_action and/or disk_error_action parameters to a valid setting of 'syslog', 'exec', 'single' or 'halt', adding the parameters if necessary.

custom_item_403.description: GEN002720 - The audit system must be configured to audit failed attempts to access files and programs - '-S creat -F success=0'

custom_item_404.description: GEN002720 - The audit system must be configured to audit failed attempts to access files and programs - '-S creat -F success=0'
custom_item_404.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_404.solution:
Edit the audit.rules file and add the following line(s) to enable auditing of failed attempts to access files and programs:

either:
-a exit,always -F arch=-S creat -F success=0

or both:
-a exit,always -F arch=-S creat -F exit=-EPERM
-a exit,always -F arch=-S creat -F exit=-EACCES

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_423.description: GEN002730 - The audit system must alert the SA when the audit storage volume approaches its capacity - 'space_left_action'
custom_item_423.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity. If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event, and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as e-mail or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_423.solution: Edit /etc/audit/auditd.conf and set the space_left_action parameter to a valid setting other than 'ignore'. If the space_left_action parameter is set to 'email' set the action_mail_acct parameter to an e-mail address for the system administrator.

custom_item_428.description: GEN002750 - The audit system must be configured to audit account creation - 'useradd'
custom_item_428.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises, and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_428.solution:
Configure execute auditing of the useradd and groupadd executables.
Add the following to audit.rules:
-w /usr/sbin/useradd -p x -k useradd
-w /usr/sbin/groupadd -p x -k groupadd
Configure append auditing of the passwd, shadow, group, and gshadow files.  Add the following to audit.rules:
-w /etc/passwd -p a -k passwd
-w /etc/shadow -p a -k shadow
-w /etc/group -p a -k group
-w /etc/gshadow -p a -k gshadow
Restart the auditd service.

custom_item_443.description: GEN002760-10 - The audit system must be configured to audit all administrative, privileged, and security actions - 'sched_setscheduler'
custom_item_443.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_443.solution:
The '-F arch='restriction is required on dual-architecture systems (such as x86_64). On dual-architecture systems, two separate rules must exist - one for each architecture supported. Use the generic architectures 'b32' and 'b64' for specifying these rules.
On single architecture systems, the '-F arch='restriction may be omitted, but if present must match either the architecture of the system or its corresponding generic architecture. The architecture of the system may be determined by running 'uname -m'. See the auditctl(8) manpage for additional details.
Any restrictions (such as with '-F') beyond those provided in the example rules are not in strict compliance with this requirement, and are a finding unless justified and documented appropriately.
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.
Procedure:
A Real Time Operating System (RTOS) provides specialized system scheduling which causes an inordinate number of messages to be produced when the sched_setparam and set_setscheduler are audited. This not only may degrade the system speed to an unusable level but obscures any forensic information which may otherwise have been useful.
Unless the operating system is a Red Hat 5 based RTOS (including MRG and AS5300) the following should also be present in /etc/audit/audit.rules

-a exit,always -F arch=-S sched_setscheduler

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_444.description: GEN002760-2 - The audit system must be configured to audit all administrative, privileged, and security actions - '/etc/audit.rules'
custom_item_444.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_444.solution:
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.

Procedure:
Add the following lines to the audit.rules file to enable auditing of administrative, privileged, and security actions:

-w /etc/audit/audit.rules

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_449.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

The '-F arch='restriction is required on dual-architecture systems (such as x86_64). On dual-architecture systems, two separate rules must exist - one for each architecture supported. Use the generic architectures 'b32' and 'b64' for specifying these rules.
On single architecture systems, the '-F arch='restriction may be omitted, but if present must match either the architecture of the system or its corresponding generic architecture. The architecture of the system may be determined by running 'uname -m'. See the auditctl(8) manpage for additional details.
Any restrictions (such as with '-F') beyond those provided in the example rules are not in strict compliance with this requirement, and are a finding unless justified and documented appropriately.
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.
Procedure:
Add the following lines to the audit.rules file to enable auditing of administrative, privileged, and security actions:

-a exit,always -F arch=-S sethostname

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_451.description: GEN002760-9 - The audit system must be configured to audit all administrative, privileged, and security actions - 'sched_setparam'
custom_item_451.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_451.solution:
The '-F arch='restriction is required on dual-architecture systems (such as x86_64). On dual-architecture systems, two separate rules must exist - one for each architecture supported. Use the generic architectures 'b32' and 'b64' for specifying these rules.
On single architecture systems, the '-F arch='restriction may be omitted, but if present must match either the architecture of the system or its corresponding generic architecture. The architecture of the system may be determined by running 'uname -m'. See the auditctl(8) manpage for additional details.
Any restrictions (such as with '-F') beyond those provided in the example rules are not in strict compliance with this requirement, and are a finding unless justified and documented appropriately.
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.
Procedure:
A Real Time Operating System (RTOS) provides specialized system scheduling which causes an inordinate number of messages to be produced when the sched_setparam and set_setscheduler are audited. This not only may degrade the system speed to an unusable level but obscures any forensic information which may otherwise have been useful.
Unless the operating system is a Red Hat 5 based RTOS (including MRG and AS5300) the following should also be present in /etc/audit/audit.rules

-a exit,always -F arch=-S sched_setparam

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_452.description: GEN002800 - The audit system must be configured to audit login, logout, and session initiation - 'faillog'
custom_item_452.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_452.solution:
Ensure logins

Procedure:
Modify /etc/audit/audit.rules to contain:

-w /var/log/faillog -p wa
-w /var/log/lastlog -p wa

custom_item_470.description: GEN002825 - The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - 'init_module'
custom_item_470.info: Actions concerning dynamic kernel modules must be recorded as they are substantial events.  Dynamic kernel modules can increase the attack surface of a system.  A malicious kernel module can be used to substantially alter the functioning of a system, often with the purpose of hiding a compromise from the SA.
custom_item_470.solution:
The '-F arch=' restriction is required on dual-architecture systems (such as x86_64). On dual-architecture systems, two separate rules must exist - one for each architecture supported. Use the generic architectures 'b32' and 'b64' for specifying these rules.
On single architecture systems, the '-F arch=' restriction may be omitted, but if present must match either the architecture of the system or its corresponding generic architecture. The architecture of the system may be determined by running 'uname -m'. See the auditctl(8) manpage for additional details.
Any restrictions (such as with '-F') beyond those provided in the example rules are not in strict compliance with this requirement, and are a finding unless justified and documented appropriately.
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.
Procedure:
Configure auditing of the init_module syscalls.
Add the following to the 'etc/audit/audit.rules' or 'etc/audit.rules' file:

-a exit,always -S init_module

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_472.description: GEN002825-3 - The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - '/sbin/insmod'
custom_item_472.info: Actions concerning dynamic kernel modules must be recorded as they are substantial events. Dynamic kernel modules can increase the attack surface of a system. A malicious kernel module can be used to substantially alter the functioning of a system, often with the purpose of hiding a compromise from the SA.
custom_item_472.solution:
The use of audit keys consistent with the provided example is encouraged to provide for uniform audit logs, however omitting the audit key or using an alternate audit key is not a finding.
Procedure:

Configure auditing of the /sbin/insmod, files.
Add the following to the 'etc/audit/audit.rules' or 'etc/audit.rules' file:
-w /sbin/insmod -p x

Restart the auditd service.
# service auditd restart

custom_item_477.description: GEN002870 - The system must be configured to send audit records to a remote audit server - '/boot/grub/grub.conf audit=1'
custom_item_477.info: System/Audit records contain evidence that can be used in the investigation of compromised systems. To prevent this evidence from compromise, it must be sent to a separate system continuously. Methods for sending audit records include, but are not limited to, system audit tools used to send logs directly to another host or through the system's syslog service to another host.
custom_item_477.solution:
Configure the system to send audit records to a remote server.

Procedure:
These instructions assume a known remote audit server is available to this system.
Modify /etc/syslog.conf or /etc/rsyslog.conf to contain a line sending all audit records to a remote audit server. The server is specified by placing an '@' before the DNS name or IP address in the line.

*.* @Edit the 'active' line in /etc/audisp/plugins.d/syslog.conf so it shows 'active = yes'.

Restart audit and syslog:
# service auditd restart
# service syslog restart
Or:
# service rsyslog restart

custom_item_482.description: GEN002960 - Access to the cron utility must be controlled using the cron.allow and/or cron.deny file(s) - 'cron.allow exists'
custom_item_482.info: The cron facility allows users to execute recurring jobs on a regular and unattended basis. The cron.allow file designates accounts allowed to enter and execute jobs using the cron facility. If the cron.allow file is not present, users listed in the cron.deny file are not allowed to use the cron facility. Improper configuration of cron may open the facility up for abuse by system intruders and malicious users.
custom_item_482.solution: Create /etc/cron.allow and/or /etc/cron.deny with appropriate content and reboot the system to ensure no lingering cron jobs are processed.

custom_item_483.description: GEN002960 - Access to the cron utility must be controlled using the cron.allow and/or cron.deny file(s) - 'cron.deny exists'
custom_item_483.info: The cron facility allows users to execute recurring jobs on a regular and unattended basis. The cron.allow file designates accounts allowed to enter and execute jobs using the cron facility. If the cron.allow file is not present, users listed in the cron.deny file are not allowed to use the cron facility. Improper configuration of cron may open the facility up for abuse by system intruders and malicious users.
custom_item_483.solution: Create /etc/cron.allow and/or /etc/cron.deny with appropriate content and reboot the system to ensure no lingering cron jobs are processed.

custom_item_484.description: GEN002980 - The cron.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_484.info: A readable and/or writable cron.allow file by users other than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.
custom_item_484.solution:
Change the mode of the cron.allow file to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.allow

custom_item_485.description: GEN002990 - The cron.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_485.info: A readable and/or writeable cron.allow file by other users than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.
custom_item_485.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/cron.allow

custom_item_486.description: GEN003040 - Crontabs must be owned by root or the crontab creator - '/var/spool/cron/*'
custom_item_486.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.
custom_item_486.solution:
Change the crontab owner to root or the crontab creator.

custom_item_501.description: GEN003060 - System accounts must not be listed in cron.allow or must be included in cron.deny - 'bin' - cron.deny
custom_item_501.info: To centralize the management of privileged account crontabs, of the default system accounts, only root may have a crontab.
custom_item_501.solution: Remove default system accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, or others, traditionally UID less than 500) from the cron.allow file if it exists, or add those accounts to the cron.deny file.

custom_item_557.description: GEN003120 - Cron and crontab directories must be owned by root or bin - '/var/spool/cron'
custom_item_557.info: Incorrect ownership of the cron or crontab directories could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter cron jobs and run automated jobs as privileged users.  Failure to give ownership of cron or crontab directories to root or to bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_557.solution:
Change the mode of the crontab directories.
# chown root

custom_item_572.description: GEN003160 - Cron logging must be implemented - rsyslog.conf
custom_item_572.info: Cron logging can be used to trace the successful or unsuccessful execution of cron jobs. It can also be used to spot intrusions into the use of the cron facility by unauthorized and malicious users.
custom_item_572.solution: Edit /etc/syslog.conf or /etc/rsyslog.conf and setup cron logging

custom_item_574.description: GEN003160 - Cron logging must be implemented - syslog.conf

custom_item_575.description: GEN003180 - The cronlog file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_575.info: Cron logs contain reports of scheduled system activities and must be protected from unauthorized access or manipulation.
custom_item_575.solution:
Change the mode of the cron log file.
# chmod 0600 /var/log/cron

custom_item_576.description: GEN003190 - The cron log files must not have extended ACLs.

# setfacl --remove-all /var/log/cron

custom_item_577.description: GEN003200 - The cron.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_577.info: If file permissions for cron.deny are more permissive than 0600, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.
custom_item_577.solution:
Change the mode of the cron.deny file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.deny

custom_item_578.description: GEN003210 - The cron.deny file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_578.info: If there are excessive file permissions for the cron.deny file, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.
custom_item_578.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/cron.deny

custom_item_579.description: GEN003220 - Cron programs must not set the umask to a value less restrictive than 077 - '/var/spool/cron/*'
custom_item_579.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask is often represented as a 4-digit octal number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.
custom_item_579.solution: Edit cron script files and modify the umask to 077.

custom_item_585.description: GEN003240 - The cron.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_585.info: If the owner of the cron.allow file is not set to root, bin, or sys, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or to edit sensitive information.

custom_item_586.description: GEN003245 - The at.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_586.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Unauthorized modification of the at.allow file could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' users and the granting of the ability to run 'at' jobs to unauthorized users.
custom_item_586.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/at.allow

custom_item_587.description: GEN003250 - The cron.allow file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
custom_item_587.info: If the group of the cron.allow is not set to root, bin, sys, or cron, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or edit the list of users permitted to use cron.  Unauthorized modification of this file could cause Denial of Service to authorized cron users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run cron jobs.
custom_item_587.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/cron.allow

custom_item_588.description: GEN003252 - The at.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_588.info: The 'at' daemon control files restrict access to scheduled job manipulation and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of the at.deny file could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run 'at' jobs.
custom_item_588.solution:
Change the mode of the file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/at.deny

custom_item_590.description: GEN003260 - The cron.deny file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.

custom_item_592.description: GEN003280 - Access to the 'at' utility must be controlled via the at.allow and/or at.deny file(s).

custom_item_593.description: GEN003280 - Access to the 'at' utility must be controlled via the at.allow and/or at.deny file(s).

custom_item_594.description: GEN003300 - The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists.

custom_item_595.description: GEN003300 - The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists.
custom_item_595.info: On some systems, if there is no at.allow file and there is an empty at.deny file, then the system assumes everyone has permission to use the 'at' facility.  This could create an insecure setting in the case of malicious users or system intruders.
custom_item_595.solution: Add appropriate users to the at.deny file, or remove the empty at.deny file if an at.allow file exists.

custom_item_597.description: GEN003320 - System accounts must not be listed in at.allow or must be included in at.deny - 'bin' - at.deny
custom_item_597.info: Default accounts, such as bin, sys, adm, uucp, daemon, and others, should never have access to the 'at' facility.  This would create a possible vulnerability open to intruders or malicious users.
custom_item_597.solution: Remove the default accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, and others, traditionally UID less than 500) from the at.allow file.
