custom_item_625.description: GEN003340 - The at.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_625.info: Permissions more permissive than 0600 (read, write and execute for the owner) may allow unauthorized or malicious access to the at.allow and/or at.deny files.
custom_item_625.solution:
Change the mode of the at.allow file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/at.allow

custom_item_626.description: GEN003400 - The 'at' directory must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_626.info: If the 'at' directory has a mode more permissive than 0755, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or to edit files containing sensitive information within the 'at' directory.  Unauthorized modifications could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' jobs.
custom_item_626.solution:
Change the mode of the 'at' directory to 0755.

Procedure:
# chmod 0755

custom_item_627.description: GEN003410 - The 'at' directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_627.info: If the 'at' directory has an extended ACL, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or to edit files containing sensitive information within the 'at' directory.  Unauthorized modifications could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' jobs.
custom_item_627.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the directory.
# setfacl --remove-all /var/spool/at

custom_item_628.description: GEN003420 - The 'at' directory must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_628.info: If the owner of the 'at' directory is not root, bin, or sys, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit files containing sensitive information within the directory.
custom_item_628.solution:
Change the owner of the 'at' directory to root, bin, sys, or system.

Procedure:
# chown<'at' directory>

custom_item_629.description: GEN003430 - The 'at' directory must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
custom_item_629.info: If the group of the 'at' directory is not root, bin, sys, or cron, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit files containing sensitive information within the directory.
custom_item_629.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file to root, bin, sys, daemon or cron.

Procedure:
# chgrp<'at' directory>

custom_item_630.description: GEN003440 - 'At' jobs must not set the umask to a value less restrictive than 077.
custom_item_630.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask is often represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.
custom_item_630.solution: Edit 'at' jobs or referenced scripts to remove 'umask' commands that set umask to a value less restrictive than 077.

custom_item_631.description: GEN003460 - The at.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_631.info: If the owner of the at.allow file is not set to root, bin, or sys, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit sensitive information contained within the file.
custom_item_631.solution:
Change the owner of the at.allow file.
# chown root /etc/at.allow

custom_item_632.description: GEN003470 - The at.allow file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
custom_item_632.info: If the group owner of the at.allow file is not set to root, bin, sys, or cron, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit the list of users permitted to run 'at' jobs.  Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run 'at' jobs.
custom_item_632.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/at.allow

custom_item_633.description: GEN003480 - The at.deny file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_633.info: If the owner of the at.deny file is not set to root, bin, or sys, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit sensitive information contained within the file.
custom_item_633.solution:
Change the owner of the at.deny file.
# chown root /etc/at.deny

custom_item_634.description: GEN003490 - The at.deny file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
custom_item_634.info: If the group owner of the at.deny file is not set to root, bin, sys, or cron, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or edit sensitive information contained within the file.  Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run 'at' jobs.
custom_item_634.solution:
Change the group ownership of the at.deny file to root, sys, bin, or cron.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/at.deny

custom_item_635.description: GEN003500 - Process core dumps must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_635.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed. Process core dump files can be of significant size and their use can result in file systems filling to capacity, which may result in Denial of Service. Process core dumps can be useful for software debugging.
custom_item_635.solution: Edit /etc/security/limits.conf and set a hard limit for 'core' to 0 for all users. A new login will be required for the changes to take effect.

custom_item_636.description: GEN003510 - Kernel core dumps must be disabled unless needed. 'process'
custom_item_636.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  Kernel core dumps may consume a considerable amount of disk space and may result in Denial of Service by exhausting the available space on the target file system.  The kernel core dump process may increase the amount of time a system is unavailable due to a crash.  Kernel core dumps can be useful for kernel debugging.
custom_item_636.solution:
Disable kdump.
# service kdump stop
# chkconfig kdump off
custom_item_636.name: kdump

custom_item_637.description: GEN003510 - Kernel core dumps must be disabled unless needed. 'chkconfig'
custom_item_637.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  Kernel core dumps may consume a considerable amount of disk space and may result in Denial of Service by exhausting the available space on the target file system.  The kernel core dump process may increase the amount of time a system is unavailable due to a crash.  Kernel core dumps can be useful for kernel debugging.
custom_item_637.solution:
Disable kdump.
# service kdump stop
# chkconfig kdump off

custom_item_638.description: GEN003520 - The kernel core dump data directory must be owned by root.
custom_item_638.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash. As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly. If the kernel core dump data directory is not owned by root, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_638.solution:
Change the owner of the kernel core dump data directory to root.
# chown root

custom_item_639.description: GEN003521 - The kernel core dump data directory must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_639.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly.  If the kernel core dump data directory is not group-owned by a system group, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_639.solution:
Change the group-owner of the kernel core dump data directory.
# chgrp root

custom_item_640.description: GEN003522 - The kernel core dump data directory must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
custom_item_640.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash. As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly. If the mode of the kernel core dump data directory is more permissive than 0700, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify kernel core dump data files.
custom_item_640.solution:
Set the permissions on the kernel core dump data directory to 0700.
# chmod 0700

custom_item_641.description: GEN003523 - The kernel core dump data directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_641.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash. As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly. If there is an extended ACL for the kernel core dump data directory, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify kernel core dump data files.
custom_item_641.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the directory.
# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_642.description: GEN003540 - The system must implement non-executable program stacks - 'RedHat release'

custom_item_643.description: GEN003540 - The system must implement non-executable program stacks - 'kernel.exec-shield'
custom_item_643.info: A common type of exploit is the stack buffer overflow.  An application receives, from an attacker, more data than it is prepared for and stores this information on its stack, writing beyond the space reserved for it.  This can be designed to cause execution of the data written on the stack.  One mechanism to mitigate this vulnerability is for the system to not allow the execution of instructions in sections of memory identified as part of the stack.
custom_item_643.solution: Examine /etc/sysctl.conf for 'kernel.exec-shield' and 'kernel.randomize_va_space' entries and if found remove them. The system default of '1' enables these modules.

custom_item_644.description: GEN003540 - The system must implement non-executable program stacks - 'kernel.randomize_va_space'
custom_item_644.info: A common type of exploit is the stack buffer overflow.  An application receives, from an attacker, more data than it is prepared for and stores this information on its stack, writing beyond the space reserved for it.  This can be designed to cause execution of the data written on the stack.  One mechanism to mitigate this vulnerability is for the system to not allow the execution of instructions in sections of memory identified as part of the stack.
custom_item_644.solution: Examine /etc/sysctl.conf for 'kernel.exec-shield' and 'kernel.randomize_va_space' entries and if found remove them. The system default of '1' enables these modules.

custom_item_645.description: GEN003581 - Network interfaces must not be configured to allow user control.
custom_item_645.info: Configuration of network interfaces should be limited to privileged users.  Manipulation of network interfaces may result in a Denial of Service or bypass of network security mechanisms.
custom_item_645.solution: Edit the configuration for the user-controlled interface and remove the 'USERCTL=yes' configuration line or set to 'USERCTL=no'.

custom_item_646.description: GEN003600 - The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route'
custom_item_646.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_646.solution:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_647.description: GEN003600 - The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route'
custom_item_647.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_647.solution:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_648.description: GEN003601 - TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately.
custom_item_648.info: To provide some mitigation to TCP Denial of Service attacks, the TCP backlog queue sizes must be set to at least 1280 or in accordance with product-specific guidelines.
custom_item_648.solution:
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for "net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog=1280".

Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_649.description: GEN003602 - The system must not process Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests - 'timestamp-request -j DROP'
custom_item_649.info: The processing of (ICMP) timestamp requests increases the attack surface of the system.
custom_item_649.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP TIMESTAMP_REQUESTs. This is done by rejecting ICMP type 13 and 14 messages at the firewall.

Procedure:
Edit /etc/sysconfig/iptables to add:

-A RH-Firewall-1-INPUT -p ICMP --icmp-type timestamp-request -j DROP
-A RH-Firewall-1-INPUT -p ICMP --icmp-type timestamp-reply -j DROP

Restart the firewall:
# service iptables restart

custom_item_650.description: GEN003602 - The system must not process Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests - 'timestamp-reply -j DROP'
custom_item_650.info: The processing of (ICMP) timestamp requests increases the attack surface of the system.
custom_item_650.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP TIMESTAMP_REQUESTs. This is done by rejecting ICMP type 13 and 14 messages at the firewall.

Procedure:
Edit /etc/sysconfig/iptables to add:

-A RH-Firewall-1-INPUT -p ICMP --icmp-type timestamp-request -j DROP
-A RH-Firewall-1-INPUT -p ICMP --icmp-type timestamp-reply -j DROP

Restart the firewall:
# service iptables restart

custom_item_651.description: GEN003603 - The system must not respond to ICMPv4 echoes sent to a broadcast address.
custom_item_651.info: Responding to broadcast (ICMP) echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.
custom_item_651.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP ECHO_REQUESTs sent to broadcast addresses. Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1' and reload the sysctls.

Procedure:
# echo 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1' >> /etc/sysctl.conf
# sysctl -p

custom_item_652.description: GEN003604 - The system must not respond to ICMP timestamp requests sent to a broadcast address.
custom_item_652.info: The processing of (ICMP) timestamp requests increases the attack surface of the system.  Responding to broadcast ICMP timestamp requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.
custom_item_652.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP TIMESTAMP_REQUESTs sent to broadcast addresses. Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1' and reload the sysctls.

Procedure:
# echo 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1' >> /etc/sysctl.conf
# sysctl -p

custom_item_653.description: GEN003607 - The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route'
custom_item_653.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the handling of source-routed traffic destined to the system itself, not to traffic forwarded by the system to another system, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_653.solution:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_654.description: GEN003607 - The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route'
custom_item_654.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the handling of source-routed traffic destined to the system itself, not to traffic forwarded by the system to another system, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_654.solution:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_655.description: GEN003608 - Proxy ARP must not be enabled on the system.
custom_item_655.info: Proxy ARP allows a system to respond to ARP requests on one interface on behalf of hosts connected to another interface.  If this function is enabled when not required, addressing information may be leaked between the attached network segments.
custom_item_655.solution:
Configure the system to not use proxy ARP.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.proxy_arp=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.proxy_arp=0'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_656.description: GEN003609 - The system must ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages - 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects'
custom_item_656.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated.  An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
custom_item_656.solution:
Configure the system to not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_657.description: GEN003609 - The system must ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages - 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'
custom_item_657.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated.  An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
custom_item_657.solution:
Configure the system to not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_658.description: GEN003610 - The system must not send IPv4 ICMP redirects - 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'
custom_item_658.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination.  These messages contain information from the system's route table possibly revealing portions of the network topology.
custom_item_658.solution:
Configure the system to not send IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects=0'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_659.description: GEN003610 - The system must not send IPv4 ICMP redirects - 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects'
custom_item_659.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination.  These messages contain information from the system's route table possibly revealing portions of the network topology.
custom_item_659.solution:
Configure the system to not send IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects=0'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_660.description: GEN003611 - The system must log martian packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians'
custom_item_660.info: Martian packets are packets containing addresses known by the system to be invalid.  Logging these messages allows the SA to identify misconfigurations or attacks in progress.
custom_item_660.solution:
Configure the system to log martian packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians=1' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.log_martians=1'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_661.description: GEN003611 - The system must log martian packets - 'net.ipv4.conf.default.log_martians'
custom_item_661.info: Martian packets are packets containing addresses known by the system to be invalid.  Logging these messages allows the SA to identify misconfigurations or attacks in progress.
custom_item_661.solution:
Configure the system to log martian packets.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians=1' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.log_martians=1'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_662.description: GEN003612 - The system must be configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
custom_item_662.info: A TCP SYN flood attack can cause Denial of Service by filling a system's TCP connection table with connections in the SYN_RCVD state.  Syncookies are a mechanism used to only track a connection when a subsequent ACK is received, verifying the initiator is attempting a valid connection and is not a flood source.  This technique does not operate in a fully standards-compliant manner, but is only activated when a flood condition is detected, and allows defense of the system while continuing to service valid requests.
custom_item_662.solution:
Configure the system to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies=1'.
# sysctl -p

custom_item_663.description: GEN003619 - The system must not be configured for network bridging.
custom_item_663.info: Some systems have the ability to bridge or switch frames (link-layer forwarding) between multiple interfaces.  This can be useful in a variety of situations but, if enabled when not needed, has the potential to bypass network partitioning and security.
custom_item_663.solution:
Configure the system to not use bridging.
# rmmod bridge
Edit /etc/modprobe.conf and add a line such as 'install bridge /bin/false' to prevent the loading of the bridge module.

custom_item_664.description: GEN003620 - A separate file system must be used for user home directories (such as /home or equivalent).
custom_item_664.info: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
custom_item_664.solution: Migrate the /home (or equivalent) path onto a separate file system.

custom_item_667.description: GEN003624 - The system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).

custom_item_668.description: GEN003640 - The root file system must employ journaling or another mechanism that ensures file system consistency - 'fs type'
custom_item_668.info: File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash,  preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost.  Journaling file systems typically do not require consistency checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability.  Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency also satisfying this requirement.
custom_item_668.solution: Implement file system journaling for the root file system, or use a file system with other mechanisms to ensure file system consistency. If the root file system supports journaling, enable it. If the file system does not support journaling or another mechanism to ensure file system consistency, a migration to a different file system will be necessary.

custom_item_669.description: GEN003640 - The root file system must employ journaling or another mechanism that ensures file system consistency - 'nolog option'

Journaling file systems typically do not require consistency checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability.  Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency also satisfying this requirement.
custom_item_669.solution: Implement file system journaling for the root file system, or use a file system with other mechanisms to ensure file system consistency. If the root file system supports journaling, enable it. If the file system does not support journaling or another mechanism to ensure file system consistency, a migration to a different file system will be necessary.

custom_item_670.description: GEN003650 - All local file systems must employ journaling or another mechanism that ensures file system consistency.
custom_item_670.info: File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost.  Journaling file systems typically do not require consistency checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability.  Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency also satisfying this requirement.
custom_item_670.solution: Convert local file systems to use journaling or another mechanism ensuring file system consistency.

custom_item_681.description: GEN003720 - The xinetd.conf file, and the xinetd.d directory must be owned by root or bin - '/etc/xinetd.conf'
custom_item_681.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration possibly weakening the system's security posture.
custom_item_681.solution:
Change the owner of the xinetd configuration files.
# chown root /etc/xinetd.conf /etc/xinetd.d/*

custom_item_682.description: GEN003720 - The xinetd.conf file, and the xinetd.d directory must be owned by root or bin - '/etc/xinetd.d/*'

custom_item_690.description: GEN003760 - The services file must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_690.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration possibly weakening the system's security posture.

custom_item_691.description: GEN003770 - The services file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.

custom_item_692.description: GEN003780 - The services file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_692.info: The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.
custom_item_692.solution:

Procedure:

custom_item_693.description: GEN003790 - The services file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_693.info: The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  If the services file has an extended ACL, it may be possible for unauthorized users to modify the file.  Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.
custom_item_693.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.

custom_item_694.description: GEN003700 - Xinetd must be disabled or removed if no network services utilizing them are enabled.
custom_item_694.name: xinetd

custom_item_695.description: GEN003800 - Xinetd logging/tracing must be enabled - '/etc/xinetd.conf log_type'
custom_item_695.info: Inetd or xinetd logging and tracing allows the system administrators to observe the IP addresses connecting to their machines and what network services are being sought.  This provides valuable information when trying to find the source of malicious users and potential malicious users.
custom_item_695.solution:
Edit each file in the /etc/xinetd.d directory and the /etc/xinetd.conf file to contain:
log_type = SYSLOG authpriv
log_on_success = HOST PID USERID EXIT
log_on_failure = HOST USERID

The /etc/xinetd.conf file contains default values that will hold true for all services unless individually modified in the service's xinetd.d file.

To make the new settings effective, restart the xinetd service:
# service xinetd restart

custom_item_713.description: GEN003850 - The telnet daemon must not be running - 'chkconfig'
custom_item_713.info: The telnet daemon provides a typically unencrypted remote access service which does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session.  If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised.
custom_item_713.solution:
Identify the telnet service running and disable it.

Verify the telnet daemon is no longer running.

custom_item_714.description: GEN003860 - The system must not have the finger service active.

custom_item_715.description: GEN003860 - The system must not have the finger service active.

custom_item_716.description: GEN003865 - Network analysis tools must not be installed - 'ethereal'
custom_item_716.info:
Network analysis tools allow for the capture of network traffic visible to the system.

If the system is being used as a network analysis/troubleshooting system then these tools are allowed if documented.
custom_item_716.solution:
Remove each network analysis tool binary from the system. Remove package items with a package manager, others remove the binary directly.

Procedure:
Find the binary file:
# find / -nameFind the package, if any, to which it belongs:
# rpm -qfRemove the package if it does not also include other software:
# rpm -eor
# yum removeIf the item to be removed is not in a package, or the entire package cannot be removed because of other software it provides, remove the item's binary file.

# rm

custom_item_722.description: GEN003900 - The hosts.lpd file (or equivalent) must not contain a '+' character - 'Listen'
custom_item_722.info: Having the '+' character in the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file allows all hosts to use local system print resources.
custom_item_722.solution:
Configure cups to use only the localhost or specified remote hosts.

Procedure:
Modify the /etc/cups/cupsd.conf file to 'Listen' only to the local machine or a known set of hosts (i.e., Listen localhost:631).
Modify the /etc/cups/cupsd.conf file '' element to 'Deny From All' and 'Allow from 127.0.0.1' or allowed host addresses.

Restart cups:
# service cups restart

custom_item_723.description: GEN003900 - The hosts.lpd file (or equivalent) must not contain a '+' character - 'Allow from'
custom_item_723.info: Having the '+' character in the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file allows all hosts to use local system print resources.
custom_item_723.solution:
Configure cups to use only the localhost or specified remote hosts.

Procedure:
Modify the /etc/cups/cupsd.conf file to 'Listen' only to the local machine or a known set of hosts (i.e., Listen localhost:631).
Modify the /etc/cups/cupsd.conf file '' element to 'Deny From All' and 'Allow from 127.0.0.1' or allowed host addresses.

Restart cups:
# service cups restart

custom_item_724.description: GEN003920 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be owned by root, bin, sys, or lp.
custom_item_724.info: Failure to give ownership of the hosts.lpd file to root, bin, sys, or lp provides the designated owner, and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify the hosts.lpd file.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_724.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/cups/printers.conf to root.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/cups/printers.conf

custom_item_725.description: GEN003930 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be group-owned by lp.
custom_item_725.info: Failure to give group-ownership of the hosts.lpd file to root, bin, sys, or system provides the members of the owning group and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify the hosts.lpd file. Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_725.solution:
Change the group-owner of the printers.conf file.

Procedure:
# chgrp lp /etc/cups/printers.conf

custom_item_726.description: GEN003940 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_726.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_726.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/cups/printers.conf file to 0664 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod 0664 /etc/cups/printers.conf

custom_item_727.description: GEN003950 - The printers.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_727.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_727.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/cups/printers.conf

custom_item_728.description: GEN003960 - The traceroute command owner must be root.
custom_item_728.info: If the traceroute command owner has not been set to root, an unauthorized user could use this command to obtain knowledge of the network topology inside the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information potentially leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_728.solution:
Change the owner of the traceroute command to root.
Example:
# chown root /bin/traceroute

custom_item_729.description: GEN003980 - The traceroute command must be group-owned by sys, bin, root, or system.
custom_item_729.info: If the group owner of the traceroute command has not been set to a system group, unauthorized users could have access to the command and use it to gain information regarding a network's topology inside of the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information potentially leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_729.solution:
Change the group-owner of the traceroute command to root.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /bin/traceroute

custom_item_730.description: GEN004000 - The traceroute file must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
custom_item_730.info: If the mode of the traceroute executable is more permissive than 0700, malicious code could be inserted by an attacker and triggered whenever the traceroute command is executed by authorized users.  Additionally, if an unauthorized user is granted executable permissions to the traceroute command, it could be used to gain information about the network topology behind the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information potentially leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_730.solution:
Change the mode of the traceroute command.
# chmod 0700 /bin/traceroute

custom_item_731.description: GEN004010 - The traceroute file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_731.info: If an extended ACL exists on the traceroute executable file, it may provide unauthorized users with access to the file.  Malicious code could be inserted by an attacker and triggered whenever the traceroute command is executed by authorized users.  Additionally, if an unauthorized user is granted executable permissions to the traceroute command, it could be used to gain information about the network topology behind the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information potentially leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_731.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /bin/traceroute

custom_item_732.description: GEN004380 - The sendmail alias files must have mode 0644 or less permissive - '/etc/aliases'
custom_item_732.info: Excessive permissions on the aliases file may permit unauthorized modification. If the alias file is modified by an unauthorized user, they may modify the file to run malicious code or redirect e-mail.
custom_item_732.solution:
Change the mode of the alias files as needed to function.

No higher than 0644.

Procedure:
for sendmail:
# chmod 0644 /etc/aliases /etc/aliases.db

for postfix (assuming the default postfix directory):
# chmod 0644 /etc/postfix/aliases /etc/postfix/aliases.db

custom_item_741.description: GEN004440 - Sendmail logging must not be set to less than nine in the sendmail.cf file.
custom_item_741.info: If Sendmail is not configured to log at level 9, system logs may not contain the information necessary for tracking unauthorized use of the sendmail service.
custom_item_741.solution: Edit the sendmail.cf file, locate the 'O L' or 'LogLevel' entry and change it to 9.

custom_item_742.description: GEN004460 - The system syslog service must log informational and more severe SMTP service messages.
custom_item_742.info: If informational and more severe SMTP service messages are not logged, malicious activity on the system may go unnoticed.
custom_item_742.solution: Edit the syslog.conf or rsyslog.conf file and add a configuration line specifying an appropriate destination for 'mail.crit' or 'mail.*' syslog messages.

custom_item_743.description: GEN004480 - The SMTP service log file must be owned by root.
custom_item_743.info: If the SMTP service log file is not owned by root, then unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide a system compromise.
custom_item_743.solution:
Change the ownership of the sendmail log file.

Procedure:
The fix procedure is the same for both sendmail and Postfix.
# chown root

custom_item_744.description: GEN004500 - The SMTP service log file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_744.info: If the SMTP service log file is more permissive than 0644, unauthorized users may be allowed to change the log file.
custom_item_744.solution:
Change the mode of the SMTP service log file.

Procedure:
The fix procedure is the same for both sendmail and Postfix.
# chmod 0644

custom_item_745.description: GEN004510 - The SMTP service log file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_745.info: If the SMTP service log file has an extended ACL, unauthorized users may be allowed to access or to modify the log file.
custom_item_745.solution:
This fix is applicable to both Postfix and sendmail servers.
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_747.description: GEN004540 - The SMTP service HELP command must not be enabled

custom_item_748.description: GEN004540 - The SMTP service HELP command must not be enabled.
custom_item_748.info: The HELP command should be disabled to mask version information. The version of the SMTP service software could be used by attackers to target vulnerabilities present in specific software versions.
custom_item_748.solution:
To disable the SMTP HELP command, clear the Sendmail help file.
# echo -n > /etc/mail/helpfile

custom_item_751.description: GEN004560 - The SMTP service's SMTP greeting must not provide version information.

custom_item_752.description: GEN004560 - The SMTP service's SMTP greeting must not provide version information.
custom_item_752.info: The version of the SMTP service can be used by attackers to plan an attack based on vulnerabilities present in the specific version.
custom_item_752.solution:
Ensure sendmail or Postfix has been configured to mask the version information.

Procedure
for sendmail:
Edit the /etc/mail/sendmail.mc file to mask the veresion number by editing the line with 'dnl' as follows:
define('confSMTP_LOGIN_MSG', ' Mail Server Ready ; $b')dnl
rebuild the sendmail.cf file.

for Postfix:
Examine the 'smtpd_banner' line of /etc/postfix/main.conf and remove any '$mail_version' entry on it or comment the entire 'smtpd_banner' line to use the default value which does not display the version information.

custom_item_754.description: GEN004580 - The system must not use .forward files - '/etc/mail/sendmail.cf'
custom_item_754.info: The .forward file allows users to automatically forward mail to another system. Use of .forward files could allow the unauthorized forwarding of mail and could potentially create mail loops which could degrade system performance.
custom_item_754.solution:
Disable forwarding for sendmail and remove .forward files from the system

Procedure:
Edit the /etc/mail/sendmail.mc file to change the ForwardPath entry to a null path by adding the line
define('confFORWARD_PATH','')
rebuild the sendmail.cf file.
If the /etc/mail/sendmail.mc file does not exist, the sendmail.cf file should be updated directly.

Remove all .forward files on the system
# find / -name .forward -delete

custom_item_755.description: GEN004580 - The system must not use .forward files - 'find .forward'

custom_item_758.description: GEN004600 - The SMTP service must be an up-to-date version - 'sendmail'
custom_item_758.info: The SMTP service version on the system must be current to avoid exposing vulnerabilities present in unpatched versions.
custom_item_758.solution: Obtain and install a newer version of the SMTP service software (sendmail or Postfix) from RedHat.

custom_item_759.description: GEN004600 - The SMTP service must be an up-to-date version - 'postfix'
custom_item_759.info: The SMTP service version on the system must be current to avoid exposing vulnerabilities present in unpatched versions.
custom_item_759.solution: Obtain and install a newer version of the SMTP service software (sendmail or Postfix) from RedHat.

custom_item_760.description: GEN004640 - The SMTP service must not have a uudecode alias active - '/etc/aliases'
custom_item_760.info: A common configuration for older Mail Transfer Agents (MTAs) is to include an alias for the decode user. All mail sent to this user is sent to the uudecode program, which automatically converts and stores files. By sending mail to the decode or the uudecode aliases present on some systems, a remote attacker may be able to create or overwrite files on the remote host. This could possibly be used to gain remote access.
custom_item_760.solution:
Disable mail aliases for decode and uudecode. If the /etc/aliases or /usr/lib/aliases (mail alias) file contains entries for these programs, remove them or disable them by placing '#' at the beginning of the line, and then executing the new aliases command. For more information on mail aliases, refer to the man page for aliases. Disabled aliases would be similar to these examples:
# decode: |/usr/bin/uudecode
# uudecode: |/usr/bin/uuencode -d

custom_item_761.description: GEN004640 - The SMTP service must not have a uudecode alias active - '/usr/lib/aliases'
custom_item_761.info: A common configuration for older Mail Transfer Agents (MTAs) is to include an alias for the decode user. All mail sent to this user is sent to the uudecode program, which automatically converts and stores files. By sending mail to the decode or the uudecode aliases present on some systems, a remote attacker may be able to create or overwrite files on the remote host. This could possibly be used to gain remote access.
custom_item_761.solution:
Disable mail aliases for decode and uudecode. If the /etc/aliases or /usr/lib/aliases (mail alias) file contains entries for these programs, remove them or disable them by placing '#' at the beginning of the line, and then executing the new aliases command. For more information on mail aliases, refer to the man page for aliases. Disabled aliases would be similar to these examples:
# decode: |/usr/bin/uudecode
# uudecode: |/usr/bin/uuencode -d

custom_item_763.description: GEN004660 - The SMTP service must not have the EXPN feature active.
custom_item_763.info: The SMTP EXPN function allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute force attack on user accounts. EXPN may also provide additional information concerning users on the system, such as the full names of account owners.
custom_item_763.solution:
Rebuild /etc/mail/sendmail.cf with the 'noexpn' Privacy Flag set.

Procedure:
Edit /etc/mail/sendmail.mc resetting the Privacy Flags to the default:

define('confPRIVACYFLAGS', 'authwarnings,novrfy,noexpn,restrictqrun')dnl

Rebuild the sendmail.cf file with:
# make -C /etc/mail

Restart the sendmail service.
# service sendmail restart

custom_item_764.description: GEN004680 - The SMTP service must not have the VRFY feature active.
custom_item_764.info: The VRFY command allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute force attack on user accounts. VRFY may provide additional information about users on the system, such as the full names of account owners.
custom_item_764.solution:
Add the 'novrfy' flag to your sendmail in /etc/mail/sendmail.cf.

Procedure:
Edit the definition of 'confPRIVACY_FLAGS' in /etc/mail/sendmail.mc to include 'novrfy'.

Rebuild the sendmail.cf file with:
# make -C /etc/mail

Restart the sendmail service.
# service sendmail restart

custom_item_765.description: GEN004700 - The Sendmail service must not have the wizard backdoor active.
custom_item_765.info: Very old installations of the Sendmail mailing system contained a feature whereby a remote user connecting to the SMTP port can enter the WIZ command and be given an interactive shell with root privileges.
custom_item_765.solution:
If the WIZ command exists on sendmail then the version of sendmail is archaic and should be replaced with the latest version from RedHat.
WIZ is not available on any sendmail distribution of RHEL. However, if the WIZ command is enabled on sendmail, it should be disabled by adding this line to the sendmail.cf configuration file (note that it must be typed in uppercase):

OW*

For the change to take effect, kill the sendmail process, refreeze the sendmail.cf file, and restart the sendmail process.

custom_item_768.description: GEN004800 - Unencrypted FTP must not be used on the system - 'gssftp'
custom_item_768.info: :  FTP is typically unencrypted and presents confidentiality and integrity risks. FTP may be protected by encryption in certain cases, such as when used in a Kerberos environment. SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP.
custom_item_768.solution:
Disable the FTP daemons.

Procedure:
# chkconfig gssftp off
# chkconfig vsftpd off
