Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/ftpusers /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_781.description: GEN004940 - The ftpusers file must have mode 0640 or less permissive - '/etc/vsftpd.ftpusers'
custom_item_781.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_781.solution:
Change the mode of the ftpusers file to 0640.

Procedure:
For gssftp:
# chmod 0640 /etc/ftpusers

For vsftp:
# chmod 0640 /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_782.description: GEN004950 - The ftpusers file must not have an extended ACL - '/etc/vsftpd.ftpusers'
custom_item_782.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_782.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/ftpusers /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_783.description: GEN004880 - The ftpusers file must exist.

custom_item_784.description: GEN004920 - The ftpusers file must be owned by root - '/etc/vsftpd/ftpusers'
custom_item_784.info: If the file ftpusers is not owned by root, an unauthorized user may modify the file to allow unauthorized accounts to use FTP.
custom_item_784.solution:
Change the owner of the ftpusers file to root.
For gssftp:
# chown root /etc/ftpusers

For vsftp:
# chown root /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_785.description: GEN004930 - The ftpusers file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system - '/etc/vsftpd/ftpusers'
custom_item_785.info: If the ftpusers file is not group-owned by root or a system group, an unauthorized user may modify the file to allow unauthorized accounts to use FTP.
custom_item_785.solution:
Change the group owner of the ftpusers file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/ftpusers /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_786.description: GEN004940 - The ftpusers file must have mode 0640 or less permissive - '/etc/vsftpd/ftpusers'
custom_item_786.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_786.solution:
Change the mode of the ftpusers file to 0640.

Procedure:
For gssftp:
# chmod 0640 /etc/ftpusers

For vsftp:
# chmod 0640 /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_787.description: GEN004950 - The ftpusers file must not have an extended ACL - '/etc/vsftpd/ftpusers'
custom_item_787.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_787.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/ftpusers /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_788.description: GEN005000 - Anonymous FTP accounts must not have a functional shell.
custom_item_788.info: If an anonymous FTP account has been configured to use a functional shell, attackers could gain access to the shell if the account is compromised.
custom_item_788.solution: Configure anonymous FTP accounts to use a non-functional shell. If necessary, edit the /etc/passwd file to remove any functioning shells associated with the ftp account and replace them with non-functioning shells, such as /dev/null.

custom_item_790.description: GEN005040 - All FTP gssftp users must have a default umask of 077 - '/etc/xinetd.d/gssftp'
custom_item_790.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask is stored as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be zero (0).
custom_item_790.solution:
Edit the initialization files for the ftp user and set the umask to 077.

Procedure:

For gssftp:
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d/gssftp file adding '-u 077' to the server_args entry.

For vsftp:
Modify the '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf' setting 'local_umask' and 'anon_umask' to 077.

custom_item_792.description: GEN005040 - All FTP gssftp users must have a default umask of 077 - '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf local_umask'
custom_item_792.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask is stored as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be zero (0).
custom_item_792.solution:
Edit the initialization files for the ftp user and set the umask to 077.

Procedure:

For gssftp:
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d/gssftp file adding '-u 077' to the server_args entry.

For vsftp:
Modify the '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf' setting 'local_umask' and 'anon_umask' to 077.

custom_item_793.description: GEN005040 - All FTP gssftp users must have a default umask of 077 - '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf anon_umask'
custom_item_793.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask is stored as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be zero (0).
custom_item_793.solution:
Edit the initialization files for the ftp user and set the umask to 077.

Procedure:

For gssftp:
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d/gssftp file adding '-u 077' to the server_args entry.

For vsftp:
Modify the '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf' setting 'local_umask' and 'anon_umask' to 077.

custom_item_795.description: GEN005080 - The TFTP daemon must operate in 'secure mode' which provides access only to a single directory on the host file system.
custom_item_795.info: Secure mode limits TFTP requests to a specific directory.  If TFTP is not running in secure mode, it may be able to write to any file or directory and may seriously impair system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.
custom_item_795.solution: Edit /etc/xinetd.d/tftp file and specify the '-s' parameter in server_args.

custom_item_796.description: GEN005100 - The TFTP daemon must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_796.info: If TFTP runs with the setuid or setgid bit set, it may be able to write to any file or directory and may seriously impair system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.
custom_item_796.solution:
Change the mode of the TFTP daemon.

Procedure:
# chmod 0755

custom_item_797.description: GEN005120 - The TFTP daemon must be configured to vendor specifications, including a dedicated TFTP user account, a non-login shell.
custom_item_797.info: If TFTP has a valid shell, it increases the likelihood someone could log on to the TFTP account and compromise the system.
custom_item_797.solution:
Configure TFTP to use a dedicated 'tftp' user.

Procedure:
Create a dedicated 'tftp' user account if none exists.
Assign a non-login shell to the 'tftp' user account, such as /bin/false.
Assign a home directory to the 'tftp' user account.
Edit /etc/xinetd.d/tftp to have 'tftp' as the value of the 'user' parameter.

custom_item_798.description: GEN005140 - Any active TFTP daemon must be authorized and approved in the system accreditation package.
custom_item_798.info: TFTP is a file transfer protocol often used by embedded systems to obtain configuration data or software.    The service is unencrypted and does not require authentication of requests.  Data available using this service may be subject to unauthorized access or interception.
custom_item_798.solution:
Document or Disable the TFTP daemon.

If the TFTP daemon is necessary on the system, document and justify its usage for approval from the IAO.

If the TFTP daemon is not necessary on the system, turn it off.

# chkconfig tftp off
# service xinetd restart

custom_item_800.description: GEN005280 - The system must not have the UUCP service active.
custom_item_800.info: The UUCP utility is designed to assist in transferring files, executing remote commands, and sending e-mail between UNIX systems over phone lines and direct connections between systems. The UUCP utility is a primitive and arcane system with many security issues. There are alternate data transfer utilities/products that can be configured to more securely transfer data by providing for authentication as well as encryption.
custom_item_800.solution:
# chkconfig uucp off
# service uucp stop
# service xinetd restart

custom_item_801.description: GEN005300 - SNMP communities, users, and passphrases must be changed from the default.
custom_item_801.info: Whether active or not, default SNMP passwords, users, and passphrases must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s).
custom_item_801.solution: Change the default passwords. To change them, locate the file snmpd.conf. Edit the file. Locate the line system-group-read-community which has a default password of 'public' and make the password something more secure and less guessable. Do the same for the lines reading system-group-write-community, read-community, write-community, trap and trap-community. Read the information in the file carefully. The trap is defining who to send traps to, for instance, by default. It is not a password, but the name of a host.

custom_item_802.description: GEN005305 - The SNMP service must use only SNMPv3 or its successors.
custom_item_802.info: SNMP Versions 1 and 2 are not considered secure. Without the strong authentication and privacy provided by the SNMP Version 3 User-based Security Model (USM), an attacker or other unauthorized users may gain access to detailed system management information and use the information to launch attacks against the system.
custom_item_802.solution:
Edit /etc/snmpd.conf and remove references to the 'v1', 'v2c', 'community', or 'com2sec'.
Restart the SNMP service.
# service snmpd restart

custom_item_803.description: GEN005306 - SNMP must require the use of a FIPS 140-2 cryptographic hash algorithm as part of its authentication and integrity methods.
custom_item_803.info: The SNMP service must use SHA-1 or a FIPS 140-2 approved successor for authentication and integrity.
custom_item_803.solution:
Edit /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf and add the SHA keyword for any create user statement without one.
Restart the SNMP service.
# service snmpd restart

custom_item_804.description: GEN005307 - SNMP must require the use of a FIPS 140-2 encryption algorithm for protecting the privacy of SNMP messages.
custom_item_804.info: The SNMP service must use AES or a FIPS 140-2 approved successor algorithm for protecting the privacy of communications.
custom_item_804.solution:
Edit /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf and add the AES keyword for any create user statement without one.
Restart the SNMP service.
# service snmpd restart

custom_item_805.description: GEN005320 - The snmpd.conf file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_805.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.
custom_item_805.solution:
Change the mode of the SNMP daemon configuration file to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600

custom_item_806.description: GEN005340 - Management Information Base (MIB) files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_806.info: The ability to read the MIB file could impart special knowledge to an intruder or malicious user about the ability to extract compromising information about the system or network.
custom_item_806.solution:
Change the mode of MIB files to 0640.

Procedure:
# chmod 0640

custom_item_807.description: GEN005350 - Management Information Base (MIB) files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_807.info: The ability to read the MIB file could impart special knowledge to an intruder or malicious user about the ability to extract compromising information about the system or network.
custom_item_807.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_808.description: GEN005360 - The snmpd.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_808.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification. If the file is not owned by root, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
custom_item_808.solution:
Change the owner of the snmpd.conf file to root.

Procedure:
# chown root

custom_item_809.description: GEN005365 - The snmpd.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_809.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the file is not group-owned by a system group, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
custom_item_809.solution:
Change the group ownership of the SNMP configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root

custom_item_810.description: GEN005375 - The snmpd.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_810.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.
custom_item_810.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_812.description: GEN005390 - The /etc/rsyslog.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_812.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.
custom_item_812.solution:
Change the permissions of the syslog or rsyslog configuration file.
# chmod 0640 /etc/syslog.conf
Or:
# chmod 0640 /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_814.description: GEN005390 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_814.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.
custom_item_814.solution:
Change the permissions of the syslog or rsyslog configuration file.
# chmod 0640 /etc/syslog.conf
Or:
# chmod 0640 /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_816.description: GEN005395 - The /etc/rsyslog.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_816.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/rsyslog.conf file.
custom_item_816.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/syslog.conf
Or:
# setfacl -- remove-all /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_818.description: GEN005395 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_818.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.
custom_item_818.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/syslog.conf
Or:
# setfacl -- remove-all /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_819.description: GEN005400 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_819.info: If the /etc/syslog.conf file is not owned by root, unauthorized users could be allowed to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the syslog facility.
custom_item_819.solution:
Use the chown command to set the owner to root.
# chown root /etc/syslog.conf
Or:
# chown root /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_820.description: GEN005420 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_820.info: If the group owner of /etc/syslog.conf is not root, bin, or sys, unauthorized users could be permitted to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the syslog facility.
custom_item_820.solution:
Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/syslog.conf
Or
# chgrp root /etc/rsyslog.conf

custom_item_822.description: GEN005450 - The system must use a remote syslog server (loghost) - rsyslog.conf
custom_item_822.info: A syslog server (loghost) receives syslog messages from one or more systems. This data can be used as an authoritative log source in the event a system is compromised and its local logs are suspect.
custom_item_822.solution: Edit the syslog or rsyslog configuration file and add an appropriate remote syslog server.

custom_item_824.description: GEN005450 - The system must use a remote syslog server (loghost) - syslog.conf
custom_item_824.info: A syslog server (loghost) receives syslog messages from one or more systems. This data can be used as an authoritative log source in the event a system is compromised and its local logs are suspect.
custom_item_824.solution: Edit the syslog or rsyslog configuration file and add an appropriate remote syslog server.

custom_item_825.description: GEN005480 - The syslog daemon must not accept remote messages unless it is a syslog server documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_825.info: Unintentionally running a syslog server accepting remote messages puts the system at increased risk. Malicious syslog messages sent to the server could exploit vulnerabilities in the server software itself, could introduce misleading information in to the system's logs, or could fill the system's storage leading to a Denial of Service.
custom_item_825.solution: Edit /etc/sysconfig/syslog to removing the '-r' in SYSLOGD_OPTIONS. Restart the syslogd service.

custom_item_826.description: GEN005500 - The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
custom_item_826.info: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH daemon could provide immediate root access to the system.
custom_item_826.solution:
Edit the sshd_config file and set the 'Protocol' setting to '2'. If using the F-Secure SSH server, set the 'Ssh1Compatibility' setting to 'no'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_827.description: GEN005501 - The SSH client must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
custom_item_827.info: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits.  Exploits of the SSH client could provide access to the system with the privileges of the user running the client.
custom_item_827.solution: Edit the /etc/ssh/ssh_config file and add or edit a 'Protocol' configuration line not allowing versions less than 2.

custom_item_828.description: GEN005504 - The SSH daemon must only listen on management network addresses unless authorized for uses other than management.
custom_item_828.info: NOTE : Update {LISTEN_ADDRESS} to an appropriate value for the local environment.
custom_item_828.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration to specify listening network addresses designated for management traffic.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_829.description: GEN005505 - The SSH daemon must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
custom_item_829.info: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.  SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES.
custom_item_829.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and remove any ciphers not starting with '3des' or 'aes' and remove any ciphers ending with 'cbc'. If necessary, add a 'Ciphers' line.

Ciphers aes256-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes128-ctr

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_830.description: GEN005506 - The SSH daemon must be configured to not use CBC ciphers.
custom_item_830.info: The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.
custom_item_830.solution:
Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config and add or edit the 'Ciphers' line.  Only include ciphers that start with '3des' or 'aes' and do not contain 'cbc'.  For the list of available ciphers for the particular version of your software, consult the sshd_config manpage.

Restart the SSH daemon.

custom_item_831.description: GEN005507 - The SSH daemon must only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 cryptographic hash algorithms.
custom_item_831.info: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.
custom_item_831.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and remove any MACs that are not hmac-sha1 or a better hmac algorithm that is on the FIPS 140-2 approved list. If necessary, add a MACs line.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_832.description: GEN005510 - The SSH client must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
custom_item_832.info: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.  SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES.
custom_item_832.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and remove any ciphers not starting with '3des' or 'aes' and remove any ciphers ending with 'cbc'. If necessary, add a 'Ciphers' line.

custom_item_833.description: GEN005511 - The SSH client must be configured to not use CBC-based ciphers.
custom_item_833.info: The (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen-plaintext attacks and must not be used.
custom_item_833.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and remove any ciphers not starting with '3des' or 'aes' and remove any ciphers ending with 'cbc'. If necessary, add a 'Ciphers' line.

custom_item_834.description: GEN005512 - The SSH client must only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 cryptographic hash algorithms.
custom_item_834.info: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.
custom_item_834.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and remove any MACs that are not hmac-sha1 or a better hmac algorithm that is on the FIPS 140-2 approved list. If necessary, add a MACs line.

custom_item_835.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/ssh/sshd_config AllowGroups'

custom_item_836.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/ssh/sshd_config AllowUsers'

custom_item_837.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/pam.d/sshd pam_access.so required'

custom_item_838.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/ssh/sshd_config AllowGroups'
custom_item_838.info: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.
custom_item_838.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add an 'AllowGroups' or 'AllowUsers' directive specifying the groups and users allowed to have access.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

Alternatively, modify the /etc/pam.d/sshd file to include the line

account required pam_access.so accessfile=If the 'accessfile' option is not specified the default 'access.conf' file will be used. The 'access.conf' file must contain the user restriction definitions.

custom_item_839.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/ssh/sshd_config AllowUsers'
custom_item_839.info: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.
custom_item_839.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add an 'AllowGroups' or 'AllowUsers' directive specifying the groups and users allowed to have access.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

Alternatively, modify the /etc/pam.d/sshd file to include the line

account required pam_access.so accessfile=If the 'accessfile' option is not specified the default 'access.conf' file will be used. The 'access.conf' file must contain the user restriction definitions.

custom_item_840.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups - '/etc/pam.d/sshd pam_access.so required'
custom_item_840.info: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.
custom_item_840.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add an 'AllowGroups' or 'AllowUsers' directive specifying the groups and users allowed to have access.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

Alternatively, modify the /etc/pam.d/sshd file to include the line

account required pam_access.so accessfile=If the 'accessfile' option is not specified the default 'access.conf' file will be used. The 'access.conf' file must contain the user restriction definitions.

custom_item_841.description: GEN005522 - The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_841.info: If a public host key file is modified by an unauthorized user, the SSH service may be compromised.
custom_item_841.solution:
Change the permissions for the SSH public host key files.
# chmod 0644 /etc/ssh/*key.pub

custom_item_842.description: GEN005523 - The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_842.info: If an unauthorized user obtains the private SSH host key file, the host could be impersonated.
custom_item_842.solution:
Change the permissions for the SSH private host key files.
# chmod 0600 /etc/ssh/*key

custom_item_843.description: GEN005524 - The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
custom_item_843.info: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_843.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and set (add if necessary) a 'GSSAPIAuthentication' directive set to 'no'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_844.description: GEN005525 - The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
custom_item_844.info: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_844.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and set the GSSAPIAuthentication' directive set to 'no'.

custom_item_845.description: GEN005526 - The SSH daemon must not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.
custom_item_845.info: Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using GSSAPI.  If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation.  Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation.  To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability.
custom_item_845.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and set (add if necessary) the 'KerberosAuthentication' directive set to 'no'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_846.description: GEN005527 - The SSH daemon must not allow host-based authentication.
custom_item_846.info: SSH trust relationships mean a compromise on one host can allow an attacker to move trivially to other hosts.
custom_item_846.solution:
SSH's cryptographic host-based authentication is more secure than '.rhosts' authentication since hosts are cryptographically authenticated. However, it is not recommended that hosts unilaterally trust one another, even within an organization.

To disable host-based authentication, add or correct the following line in '/etc/ssh/sshd_config':

HostbasedAuthentication no

custom_item_847.description: GEN005536 - The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
custom_item_847.info: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.
custom_item_847.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit the 'StrictModes' setting value to 'yes'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_848.description: GEN005537 - The SSH daemon must use privilege separation.
custom_item_848.info: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.
custom_item_848.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit the 'UsePrivilegeSeparation' setting value to 'yes'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_849.description: GEN005538 - The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.
custom_item_849.info: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.
custom_item_849.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit the 'RhostsRSAAuthentication' setting value to 'no'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_850.description: GEN005539 - The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
custom_item_850.info: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root privileges.
custom_item_850.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit the 'Compression' setting value to 'no' or 'delayed'.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_851.description: GEN005540 - The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering - '/etc/hosts.deny'
custom_item_851.info: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.
custom_item_851.solution: Add appropriate IP restrictions for SSH to the /etc/hosts.deny and/or /etc/hosts.allow files.

custom_item_852.description: GEN005540 - The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering - '/etc/hosts.allow'
custom_item_852.info: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.
custom_item_852.solution: Add appropriate IP restrictions for SSH to the /etc/hosts.deny and/or /etc/hosts.allow files.

custom_item_853.description: GEN005550 - The SSH daemon must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner - 'Banner file has been defined'
custom_item_853.info: Failure to display the DoD logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.  The SSH service must be configured to display the DoD logon warning banner either through the SSH configuration or a wrapper program such as TCP_WRAPPERS.  The SSH daemon may also be used to provide SFTP service.  The warning banner configuration for SSH will apply to SFTP.
custom_item_853.solution:
Edit /etc/issue and the DoD login banner.

DoD Login Banners:

You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests- -not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

OR

I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.


Find the location of the banner file for sshd and examine the content:

# grep -i banner /etc/ssh/sshd_config | grep -v '^#'
# cat

Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit a 'Banner' setting referencing a file containing a logon warning banner.

Restart the SSH daemon.
# /sbin/service sshd restart

custom_item_854.info: Failure to display the DoD logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.  The SSH service must be configured to display the DoD logon warning banner either through the SSH configuration or a wrapper program such as TCP_WRAPPERS.  The SSH daemon may also be used to provide SFTP service.  The warning banner configuration for SSH will apply to SFTP.

custom_item_855.description: GEN005560 - The system must be configured with a default gateway for IPv4 if the system uses IPv4, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_855.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_855.solution: Set a default gateway for IPv4.

custom_item_856.description: GEN005570 - The system must be configured with a default gateway for IPv6 if the system uses IPv6, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_856.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_856.solution:
Add a default route for IPv6.
Edit /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 (substitute interface as appropriate).
Add an IPV6_DEFAULTGW=configuration setting.
Restart the interface.
# ifdown eth0; ifup eth0

custom_item_857.description: GEN005590 - The system must not be running any routing protocol daemons, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_857.info: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers.  If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

custom_item_858.description: GEN005600 - IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_858.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_858.solution: Edit '/etc/sysctl.conf' and set net.ipv4.ip_forward to '0'. Restart the system or run 'sysctl -p' to make the change take effect.

custom_item_859.description: GEN005610 - The system must not have IP forwarding for IPv6 enabled unless the system is an IPv6 router - 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding'
custom_item_859.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_859.solution:
Disable IPv6 forwarding.

Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=0' and 'net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_860.description: GEN005610 - The system must not have IP forwarding enabled unless the system is an IPv6 router - 'net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding'
custom_item_860.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_860.solution:
Disable IPv6 forwarding.

Edit /etc/sysctl.conf and add a setting for 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=0' and 'net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding=0'.

Reload the sysctls.
Procedure:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_862.description: GEN005740 - The NFS export configuration file must be owned by root.
custom_item_862.info: Failure to give ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root provides the designated owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_862.solution:
Change the owner of the exports file to root.

Example:
# chown root /etc/exports

custom_item_863.description: GEN005750 - The NFS export configuration file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_863.info: Failure to give group-ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root or a system group provides the designated group-owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_863.solution:
Change the group ownership of the NFS export configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/exports

custom_item_864.description: GEN005760 - The NFS export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_864.info: Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.

custom_item_865.description: GEN005770 - The NFS exports configuration file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_865.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.
custom_item_865.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/exports

custom_item_866.description: GEN005820 - The NFS anonymous UID and GID must be configured to values that have no permissions - 'anonuid'
custom_item_866.info: When an NFS server is configured to deny remote root access, a selected UID and GID are used to handle requests from the remote root user.  The UID and GID should be chosen from the system to provide the appropriate level of non-privileged access.
custom_item_866.solution: Edit '/etc/exports' and set the 'anonuid=-1' and 'anongid=-1' options for exports lacking it. Re-export the filesystems.

custom_item_867.description: GEN005820 - The NFS anonymous UID and GID must be configured to values that have no permissions - 'anongid'
custom_item_867.info: When an NFS server is configured to deny remote root access, a selected UID and GID are used to handle requests from the remote root user.  The UID and GID should be chosen from the system to provide the appropriate level of non-privileged access.
custom_item_867.solution: Edit '/etc/exports' and set the 'anonuid=-1' and 'anongid=-1' options for exports lacking it. Re-export the filesystems.

custom_item_868.description: GEN005880 - The NFS server must not allow remote root access - 'no_root_squash'
custom_item_868.info: If the NFS server allows root access to local file systems from remote hosts, this access could be used to compromise the system.
custom_item_868.solution: Edit the '/etc/exports' file and add 'root_squash' (or 'all_squash') and remove 'no_root_squash'.

custom_item_869.description: GEN005880 - The NFS server must not allow remote root access - 'all_squash / root_squash'
custom_item_869.info: If the NFS server allows root access to local file systems from remote hosts, this access could be used to compromise the system.
custom_item_869.solution: Edit the '/etc/exports' file and add 'root_squash' (or 'all_squash') and remove 'no_root_squash'.

custom_item_870.description: GEN005900 - The nosuid option must be enabled on all NFS client mounts.
custom_item_870.info: Enabling the nosuid mount option prevents the system from granting owner or group-owner privileges to programs with the suid or sgid bit set.  If the system does not restrict this access, users with unprivileged access to the local system may be able to acquire privileged access by executing suid or sgid files located on the mounted NFS file system.
custom_item_870.solution: Edit '/etc/fstab' and add the 'nosuid' option for all NFS file systems. Remount the NFS file systems to make the change take effect.

custom_item_871.description: GEN006160 - The /etc/samba/passdb.tdb and /etc/samba.secrets.tdb files must be owned by root.

custom_item_872.description: GEN006160 - The /etc/samba/passdb.tdb and /etc/samba.secrets.tdb files must be owned by root.

custom_item_873.description: GEN006060 - The system must not run the Samba service unless needed.
custom_item_873.info: Samba is a tool used for the sharing of files and printers between Windows and UNIX operating systems.  It provides access to sensitive files and, therefore, poses a security risk if compromised.
custom_item_873.solution:
If there is no functional need for Samba and the daemon is running, disable the daemon by killing the process ID as noted from the output of ps -ef |grep smbd. The samba package should also be removed or not installed if there is no functional requirement.

Procedure:
rpm -qa |grep samba

This will show whether 'samba' or 'samba3x' is installed. To remove:

rpm --erase samba
or
rpm --erase samba3x
custom_item_873.name: smbd

custom_item_874.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - 'samba-swat'
custom_item_874.info: SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba.  It modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, and must be protected from unauthorized access.  SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.  Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_874.solution:
Disable SWAT or require SWAT is only accessed via SSH.

Procedure:
If SWAT is not needed for operation of the system remove the SWAT package:
# rpm -qa|grep swat

Remove 'samba-swat' or 'samba3x-swat' depending on which one is installed
# rpm --erase samba-swat
or
# rpm --erase samba3x-swat

If SWAT is required but not at all times disable it when it is not needed.
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d file for 'swat' to contain a 'disable = yes' line.

To access using SSH:
Follow vendor configuration documentation to create an stunnel for SWAT.

custom_item_875.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - 'samba3x-swat'
custom_item_875.info: SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba.  It modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, and must be protected from unauthorized access.  SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.  Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_875.solution:
Disable SWAT or require SWAT is only accessed via SSH.

Procedure:
If SWAT is not needed for operation of the system remove the SWAT package:
# rpm -qa|grep swat

Remove 'samba-swat' or 'samba3x-swat' depending on which one is installed
# rpm --erase samba-swat
or
# rpm --erase samba3x-swat

If SWAT is required but not at all times disable it when it is not needed.
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d file for 'swat' to contain a 'disable = yes' line.

To access using SSH:
Follow vendor configuration documentation to create an stunnel for SWAT.

custom_item_876.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - '/etc/xinetd.d/swat'
custom_item_876.info: SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba.  It modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, and must be protected from unauthorized access.  SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.  Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_876.solution:
Disable SWAT or require SWAT is only accessed via SSH.

Procedure:
If SWAT is not needed for operation of the system remove the SWAT package:
# rpm -qa|grep swat

Remove 'samba-swat' or 'samba3x-swat' depending on which one is installed
# rpm --erase samba-swat
or
# rpm --erase samba3x-swat

If SWAT is required but not at all times disable it when it is not needed.
Modify the /etc/xinetd.d file for 'swat' to contain a 'disable = yes' line.

To access using SSH:
Follow vendor configuration documentation to create an stunnel for SWAT.

custom_item_878.description: GEN006100 - The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_878.info: The /etc/smb.conf file allows access to other machines on the network and grants permissions to certain users.  If it is owned by another user, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_878.solution:
Change the ownership of the smb.conf file.

Procedure:
# chown root smb.conf

custom_item_879.description: GEN006120 - The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_879.info: If the group owner of the 'smb.conf' file is not root or a system group, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_879.solution:
Change the group owner of the smb.conf file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root smb.conf

custom_item_880.description: GEN006140 - The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_880.info: If the 'smb.conf' file has excessive permissions, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_880.solution:
Change the mode of the smb.conf file to 0644 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644 smb.conf.

custom_item_881.description: GEN006150 - The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_881.info: Excessive permissions could endanger the security of the Samba configuration file and, ultimately, the system and network.
custom_item_881.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_882.description: GEN006160 - The /etc/samba/passdb.tdb and /etc/samba.secrets.tdb files must be owned by root - '/etc/samba/passdb.tdb'
custom_item_882.info: If the 'smbpasswd' file is not owned by root, it may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_882.solution:
Use the chown command to configure the files maintained by smbpasswd.
For instance:
# chown root /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_883.description: GEN006160 - The /etc/samba/passdb.tdb and /etc/samba.secrets.tdb files must be owned by root - '/etc/samba.secrets.tdb'
custom_item_883.info: If the 'smbpasswd' file is not owned by root, it may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_883.solution:
Use the chown command to configure the files maintained by smbpasswd.
For instance:
# chown root /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_884.description: GEN006180 - The smbpasswd file must be group-owned by root - '/etc/samba/passdb.tdb'
custom_item_884.info: If the smbpasswd file is not group-owned by root, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_884.solution:
Use the chgrp command to ensure that the group owner of the smbpasswd file is root.

For instance:

# chgrp root /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_885.description: GEN006180 - The smbpasswd file must be group-owned by root - '/etc/samba/secrets.tdb'
custom_item_885.info: If the smbpasswd file is not group-owned by root, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_885.solution:
Use the chgrp command to ensure that the group owner of the smbpasswd file is root.

For instance:

# chgrp root /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_886.description: GEN006200 - The smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive - '/etc/samba/passdb.tdb'
custom_item_886.info: If the smbpasswd file has a mode more permissive than 0600, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_886.solution:
Change the mode of the files maintained through smbpasswd to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_887.description: GEN006200 - The smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive - '/etc/samba/secrets.tdb'
custom_item_887.info: If the smbpasswd file has a mode more permissive than 0600, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_887.solution:
Change the mode of the files maintained through smbpasswd to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_888.description: GEN006210 - The /etc/smbpasswd file must not have an extended ACL - '/etc/samba/passdb.tdb'
custom_item_888.info: If the permissions of the 'smbpasswd' file are too permissive, it may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_888.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_889.description: GEN006210 - The /etc/smbpasswd file must not have an extended ACL - '/etc/samba/secrets.tdb'
custom_item_889.info: If the permissions of the 'smbpasswd' file are too permissive, it may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_889.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/samba/passdb.tdb /etc/samba/secrets.tdb

custom_item_890.description: GEN006220 - The smb.conf file must use the 'hosts' option to restrict access to Samba.
custom_item_890.info: Samba increases the attack surface of the system and must be restricted to communicate only with systems requiring access.
custom_item_890.solution: Edit the '/etc/samba/smb.conf' file and set the 'hosts' option to permit only authorized hosts to access Samba.

custom_item_891.description: GEN006225 - Samba must be configured to use an authentication mechanism other than 'share.'
custom_item_891.info: Samba share authentication does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.
custom_item_891.solution: Edit the '/etc/samba/smb.conf' file and change the 'security' setting to 'user' or another valid setting other than 'share'.

custom_item_892.description: GEN006230 - Samba must be configured to use encrypted passwords.
custom_item_892.info: Samba must be configured to protect authenticators.  If Samba passwords are not encrypted for storage, plain-text user passwords may be read by those with access to the Samba password file.
custom_item_892.solution: Edit the '/etc/samba/smb.conf' file and change the 'encrypt passwords' setting to 'yes'.

custom_item_893.description: GEN006235 - Samba must be configured to not allow guest access to shares.
custom_item_893.info: Guest access to shares permits anonymous access and is not permitted.
custom_item_893.solution: Edit the '/etc/samba/smb.conf' file and change the 'guest ok' setting to 'no'.

custom_item_894.description: GEN006240 - The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
custom_item_894.name: innd

custom_item_895.description: GEN006240 - The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
custom_item_895.name: nntpd

custom_item_897.description: GEN006260 - The /etc/news/incoming.conf (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive
custom_item_897.info: Excessive permissions on the 'incoming.conf' file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial-of-Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_897.solution:
Change the mode of the '/etc/news/incoming.conf' file to 0600.

# chmod 0600 /etc/news/incoming.conf

custom_item_898.description: GEN006270 - The /etc/news/incoming.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_898.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the 'incoming.conf' file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_898.solution:

custom_item_899.description: GEN006280 - The /etc/news/infeed.conf (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_899.info: Excessive permissions on the '' file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.

Change the mode of '/etc/news/infeed.conf' to 0600.
# chmod 0600 /etc/news/infeed.conf

custom_item_900.description: GEN006290 - The /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_900.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp.nolimit file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_900.solution:

# setfacl --remove-all /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit

custom_item_901.description: GEN006300 - The /etc/news/readers.conf (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive
custom_item_901.info: Excessive permissions on the readers.conf file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_901.solution:

# chmod 0600 /etc/news/readers.conf

custom_item_902.description: GEN006310 - The /etc/news/nnrp.access file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_902.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the nnrp.access file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_902.solution:

# setfacl --remove-all /etc/news/nnrp.access

custom_item_903.description: GEN006320 - The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_903.info: File permissions more permissive than 0600 for '/etc/news/passwd.nntp' may allow access to privileged information by system intruders or malicious users.
custom_item_903.solution:
Change the mode of the '/etc/news/passwd.nntp' file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/news/passwd.nntp

custom_item_904.description: GEN006330 - The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_904.info: Extended ACLs may provide excessive permissions on the  /etc/news/passwd.nntp file, which may permit unauthorized  access or modification to the NNTP configuration.
custom_item_904.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/news/passwd.nntp

custom_item_905.description: GEN006340 - Files in /etc/news must be owned by root or news.
custom_item_905.info: If critical system files are not owned by a privileged user, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_905.solution:
Change the ownership of the files in '/etc/news' to root or news.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/news/*

custom_item_906.description: GEN006360 - The files in /etc/news must be group-owned by root or news.
custom_item_906.info: If critical system files do not have a privileged group-owner, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_906.solution:
Change the group-owner of the files in '/etc/news' to root or news.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/news/*

custom_item_908.description: GEN006380 - The system must not use UDP for NIS/NIS+.
custom_item_908.info: Implementing Network Information Service (NIS) or NIS+ under UDP may make the system more susceptible to a Denial of Service attack and does not provide the same quality of service as TCP.
custom_item_908.solution: Configure the system to not use UDP for NIS and NIS+. Consult vendor documentation for the required procedure.

custom_item_909.description: GEN006400 - The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.
custom_item_909.info: Due to numerous security vulnerabilities existing within NIS, it must not be used.  Possible alternative directory services are NIS+ and LDAP.
custom_item_909.solution: Disable the use of NIS/NIS+. Use as a replacement Kerberos or LDAP.
custom_item_909.name: ypbind

custom_item_910.description: GEN006480 - The system must have a host-based intrusion detection tool installed.
custom_item_910.info: Adding host-based intrusion detection tools can provide the capability to automatically take actions in response to malicious behavior, which can provide additional agility in reacting to network threats. These tools also often include a reporting capability to provide network awareness of system, which may not otherwise exist in an organization's systems management regime.
custom_item_910.solution: Install and enable the latest McAfee HIPS package, available from Cybercom. If the system does not support the McAfee HIPS package, install and enable a supported intrusion detection system application and document its use with the Authorizing Official.

custom_item_911.description: GEN006565 - The system package management tool must be used to verify system software periodically - '/var/spool/cron/root'

custom_item_912.description: GEN006565 - The system package management tool must be used to verify system software periodically - '/etc/crontab'

custom_item_913.description: GEN006565 - The system package management tool must be used to verify system software periodically - '/etc/cron.d/*'

custom_item_915.description: GEN006570 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify ACLs.
custom_item_915.info: ACLs can provide permissions beyond those permitted through the file mode and must be verified by file integrity tools.
custom_item_915.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the 'ACL' option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure ACL checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_916.description: GEN006571 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify extended attributes.
custom_item_916.info: Extended attributes in file systems are used to contain arbitrary data and file metadata with security implications.
custom_item_916.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the 'xattrs' option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure extended attributes checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_917.description: GEN006575 - The file integrity tool must use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents.
custom_item_917.info: File integrity tools often use cryptographic hashes for verifying that file contents have not been altered.  These hashes must be FIPS 140-2 approved.
custom_item_917.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the 'sha512' option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_918.description: GEN006580 - The system must use an access control program.
custom_item_918.info: Access control programs (such as TCP_WRAPPERS) provide the ability to enhance system security posture.
custom_item_918.solution: Install and configure the tcp_wrappers package.

custom_item_920.description: GEN006600 - The system's access control program must log each system access attempt - rsyslog *.info
custom_item_920.info: If access attempts are not logged, then multiple attempts to log on to the system by an unauthorized user may go undetected.
custom_item_920.solution: Configure the access restriction program to log every access attempt. Ensure the implementation instructions for tcp_wrappers are followed so system access attempts are recorded to the system log files. If an alternate application is used, it must support this function.

custom_item_932.description: GEN006620 - The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.

custom_item_933.description: GEN006620 - The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
custom_item_933.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_933.solution: Edit the '/etc/hosts.all' and '/etc/hosts.deny' files to configure access restrictions.

custom_item_940.description: GEN006660 - Accounts must be locked upon 35 days of inactivity.
custom_item_940.info: Disabling inactive accounts ensures that accounts which may not have been responsibly removed are not available to attackers who may have compromised their credentials.
custom_item_940.solution:
To specify the number of days after a password expires (which signifies inactivity) until an account is permanently disabled, add or correct the following lines in '/etc/default/useradd', substituting '[NUM_DAYS]' appropriately:

INACTIVE=[NUM_DAYS]

A value of 35 is recommended. If a password is currently on the verge of expiration, then 35 days remain until the account is automatically disabled. However, if the password will not expire for another 60 days, then 95 days could elapse until the account would be automatically disabled. See the 'useradd' man page for more information. Determining the inactivity timeout must be done with careful consideration of the length of a 'normal' period of inactivity for users in the particular environment. Setting the timeout too low incurs support costs and also has the potential to impact availability of the system to legitimate users.

custom_item_957.description: GEN007800 - The system must not have Teredo enabled.
custom_item_957.info: Teredo is an IPv6 transition mechanism involving tunneling IPv6 packets encapsulated in IPv4 packets. Unauthorized tunneling may circumvent network security.
custom_item_957.solution: Edit startup scripts to prevent the service from running on startup.
custom_item_957.name: miredo

custom_item_958.description: GEN007820 - The system must not have IP tunnels configured - '/sbin/ip tun list'
custom_item_958.info: IP tunneling mechanisms can be used to bypass network filtering.
custom_item_958.solution:
Remove the tunnels.
# ip tun delEdit system startup scripts to prevent tunnel creation on startup.

custom_item_959.description: GEN007820 - The system must not have IP tunnels configured - '/sbin/ip -6 tun list'
custom_item_959.info: IP tunneling mechanisms can be used to bypass network filtering.
custom_item_959.solution:
Remove the tunnels.
# ip tun delEdit system startup scripts to prevent tunnel creation on startup.

custom_item_960.description: GEN007840 - The DHCP client must be disabled if not needed.
custom_item_960.info: DHCP allows for the unauthenticated configuration of network parameters on the system by exchanging information with a DHCP server.
custom_item_960.solution: Edit the '/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-*' file(s) and change the 'bootproto' setting to 'static'.

custom_item_961.description: GEN007850 - The DHCP client must not send dynamic DNS updates.

custom_item_962.description: GEN007850 - The DHCP client must not send dynamic DNS updates.
custom_item_962.info: Dynamic DNS updates transmit unencrypted information about a system including its name and address and should not be used unless needed.
custom_item_962.solution:
Edit or add the '/etc/dhclient.conf' file and add or edit the 'do-forward-updates' setting to false.

Procedure:
# echo 'do-forward-updates false;' >> /etc/dhclient.conf

custom_item_963.description: GEN007860 - The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
custom_item_963.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
custom_item_963.solution:
Configure the system to ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
Edit '/etc/sysctl.conf' and add a settings for 'net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects=0' and 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects=0'.
Restart the system for the setting to take effect.

custom_item_964.description: GEN007920 - The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets - 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding'
custom_item_964.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv6 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_964.solution:
Configure the system to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

Procedure:
Edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file to include:
net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 0
net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding = 0

Reload the kernel parameters:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_965.description: GEN007920 - The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets - 'net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding'
custom_item_965.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv6 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_965.solution:
Configure the system to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

Procedure:
Edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file to include:
net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 0
net.ipv6.conf.default.forwarding = 0

Reload the kernel parameters:
# sysctl -p

custom_item_966.description: GEN007950 - The system must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address.
custom_item_966.info: Responding to broadcast ICMP echo requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.
custom_item_966.solution:
Add an iptables rule that drops inbound IPv6 ICMP ECHO_REQUESTs sent to the all-hosts multicast address.

Edit /etc/sysconfig/ip6tables and add a rule in, or referenced by, the INPUT chain such as:
-A INPUT -p icmpv6 -d ff02::1 --icmpv6-type 128 -j DROP

Reload the iptables rules.
Procedure:
# service ip6tables restart

custom_item_967.description: GEN007960 - The 'ldd' command must be disabled unless it protects against the execution of untrusted files.

custom_item_968.description: GEN007960 - The 'ldd' command must be disabled unless it protects against the execution of untrusted files.
custom_item_968.info: The 'ldd' command provides a list of dependent libraries needed by a given binary, which is useful for troubleshooting software. Instead of parsing the binary file, some 'ldd' implementations invoke the program with a special environment variable set, which causes the system dynamic linker to display the list of libraries. Specially crafted binaries can specify an alternate dynamic linker which may cause a program to be executed instead of examined. If the program is from an untrusted source, such as in a user home directory, or a file suspected of involvement in a system compromise, unauthorized software may be executed with the rights of the user running 'ldd'.
custom_item_968.solution:
Remove the execute permissions from the 'ldd' executable.

Procedure:
# chmod a-x /usr/bin/ldd

custom_item_971.description: GEN007980 - If using LDAP for auth or account information, must use a TLS connection using FIPS 140-2 algorithms - 'ssl start_tls'
custom_item_971.info: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP requires protection.
custom_item_971.solution: Edit '/etc/ldap.conf' and add a 'ssl start_tls' and 'tls_ciphers' options with only FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.

custom_item_974.description: GEN008000 - If using LDAP for auth or account info, certs used must be provided from DoD or an approved external PKI - 'tls_cert'
custom_item_974.info: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP requires authentication.
custom_item_974.solution: Edit '/etc/ldap.conf' and add or edit the 'tls_cert' setting to reference a file containing a client certificate issued by DoD PKI or a DoD-approved external PKI.

custom_item_975.description: GEN008020 - If using LDAP for auth or acct info, the LDAP TLS connection must require a cert that has a valid trust path to a trusted CA.
custom_item_975.info: The NSS LDAP service provides user mappings which are a vital component of system security.  Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP for NSS require authentication.
custom_item_975.solution: Edit '/etc/ldap.conf' and add or set the 'tls_checkpeer' setting to 'yes'.

custom_item_976.description: GEN008040 - If using LDAP for auth or account information, the system must check that the LDAP server's certificate has not been revoked.
custom_item_976.info: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP requires authentication.
custom_item_976.solution: Edit '/etc/ldap.conf' and add or set the 'tls_crlcheck' setting to 'all'.

custom_item_977.description: GEN008050 - If using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf file (or equivalent) must not contain passwords.
custom_item_977.info: The authentication of automated LDAP connections between systems must not use passwords since more secure methods are available, such as PKI and Kerberos. Additionally, the storage of unencrypted passwords on the system is not permitted.
custom_item_977.solution: Edit the '/etc/ldap.conf' file to use anonymous binding by removing the 'bindpw' option.

custom_item_978.description: GEN008060 - If using LDAP for authentication or account information the /etc/ldap.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.

custom_item_991.description: GEN008200 - If using LDAP for auth or account info, the TLS cert file and/or directory (as appropriate) must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_991.info: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security.  The LDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_991.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the certificate file.

Procedure:
For each certificate file found remove all extended permissions

# setfacl --remove-all

custom_item_992.info: The NSS LDAP service provides user mappings which are a vital component of system security.  Its configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_992.solution:
Change the ownership of the file.
# chown root

custom_item_993.description: GEN008240 - Using LDAP for auth or acct info, TLS cert must be group-owned by root,bin,sys,or system - '/etc/openldap/cacerts/cert.pem'

custom_item_993.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.

Procedure:

custom_item_998.description: GEN008340 - If using LDAP for auth or acct info, the LDAP TLS key must have mode 0600 or less permissive - '/etc/openldap/cacerts/key.pem'

This will still be a finding, as these permissions provide users with access to system authenticators.

custom_item_1000.description: GEN008420 - The system must use available memory address randomization techniques.
custom_item_1000.info: Successful exploitation of buffer overflow vulnerabilities relies in some measure to having a predictable address structure of the executing program. Address randomization techniques reduce the probability of a successful exploit.
custom_item_1000.solution: Edit the kernel boot parameters, or '/etc/sysctl.conf', and set exec-shield to '1'. Reboot the system.

custom_item_1001.description: GEN008440 - Automated file system mounting tools must not be enabled unless needed - 'process'
custom_item_1001.info: Automated file system mounting tools may provide unprivileged users with the ability to access local media and network shares. If this access is not necessary for the system's operation, it must be disabled to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to these resources.
custom_item_1001.solution:
Stop and disable the autofs service.
# service autofs stop
# chkconfig autofs off
custom_item_1001.name: autofs

custom_item_1002.description: GEN008440 - Automated file system mounting tools must not be enabled unless needed - 'chkconfig'
custom_item_1002.info: Automated file system mounting tools may provide unprivileged users with the ability to access local media and network shares. If this access is not necessary for the system's operation, it must be disabled to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to these resources.
custom_item_1002.solution:
Stop and disable the autofs service.

# chkconfig autofs off

custom_item_1003.description: GEN008460 - The system must have USB disabled unless needed - 'kernel - /boot/grub/grub.conf'
custom_item_1003.info: USB is a common computer peripheral interface. USB devices may include storage devices with the potential to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.
custom_item_1003.solution: Edit the grub bootloader file '/boot/grub/grub.conf' or '/boot/grub/menu.lst' by appending the 'nousb' parameter to the kernel boot line.
