custom_item_1006.description: GEN008480 - The system must have USB Mass Storage disabled unless needed - '/etc/modprobe.conf'

custom_item_1007.description: GEN008480 - The system must have USB Mass Storage disabled unless needed - '/etc/modprobe.d/*'

custom_item_1008.description: GEN008500 - The system must have IEEE 1394 (Firewire) disabled unless needed - '/etc/modprobe.conf'

custom_item_1009.description: GEN008500 - The system must have IEEE 1394 (Firewire) disabled unless needed - '/etc/modprobe.d/*'

custom_item_1010.description: GEN008520 - The system must employ a local firewall.
custom_item_1010.info: A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave.  If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.
custom_item_1010.solution:
Enable the system's local firewall.
# chkconfig iptables on
# service iptables start

custom_item_1011.description: GEN008540 - The system's local firewall must implement a deny-all, allow-by-exception policy.
custom_item_1011.info: A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave.  If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.
custom_item_1011.solution:
Edit '/etc/sysconfig/iptables' and add a default deny rule.

An example of a default deny rule:
-A RH-Firewall-1-INPUT -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-host-prohibited

Restart the iptable service.
# service iptables restart

custom_item_1012.description: GEN008660 - For using GRUB, the system must be configured with GRUB as the default unless another boot loader has been authorized.
custom_item_1012.info: GRUB is a versatile boot loader used by several platforms that can provide authentication for access to the system or boot loader.
custom_item_1012.solution: Configure the system to use the GRUB bootloader or document, justify, and authorize the alternate bootloader.

custom_item_1013.description: GEN008700 - The system boot loader must require authentication - '/boot/grub/grub.conf'
custom_item_1013.info: If the system's boot loader does not require authentication, users with console access to the system may be able to alter the system boot configuration or boot the system into single user or maintenance mode, which could result in Denial of Service or unauthorized privileged access to the system.
custom_item_1013.solution: The GRUB console boot loader can be configured to use an MD5 encrypted password by adding password --md5 password-hash to the '/boot/grub/grub.conf' file. Use '/sbin/grub-md5-crypt' to generate MD5 passwords from the command line.

custom_item_1014.description: GEN008700 - The system boot loader must require authentication - '/boot/grub/menu.lst'
custom_item_1014.info: If the system's boot loader does not require authentication, users with console access to the system may be able to alter the system boot configuration or boot the system into single user or maintenance mode, which could result in Denial of Service or unauthorized privileged access to the system.
custom_item_1014.solution: The GRUB console boot loader can be configured to use an MD5 encrypted password by adding password --md5 password-hash to the '/boot/grub/grub.conf' file. Use '/sbin/grub-md5-crypt' to generate MD5 passwords from the command line.

custom_item_1015.description: GEN008720 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_1015.info: File permissions greater than 0600 on boot loader configuration files could allow an unauthorized user to view or modify sensitive information pertaining to system boot instructions.
custom_item_1015.solution:
Change the mode of the grub.conf file to 0600.

# chmod 0600 /boot/grub/grub.conf

custom_item_1016.description: GEN008740 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_1016.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  If extended ACLs are present on the system's boot loader configuration file(s), these files may be vulnerable to unauthorized access or modification, which could compromise the system's boot process.
custom_item_1016.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# setfacl --remove-all /etc/grub.conf

custom_item_1017.description: GEN008760 - The system's boot loader configuration files must be owned by root.
custom_item_1017.info: The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of these files resulting from improper ownership could compromise the system's boot loader configuration.
custom_item_1017.solution:
Change the ownership of the file.
# chown root /boot/grub/grub.conf

custom_item_1018.description: GEN008780 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_1018.info: The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected.  Unauthorized modifications resulting from improper group ownership may compromise the boot loader configuration.
custom_item_1018.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.
# chgrp root /boot/grub/grub.conf

custom_item_1019.description: GEN008800 - The package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of packages during installation.

custom_item_1020.description: GEN008800 - The package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of packages during installation - '/etc/yum.conf'
custom_item_1020.info: To prevent the installation of software from unauthorized sources, the system package management tool must use cryptographic algorithms to verify the packages are authentic.
custom_item_1020.solution: Edit the YUM configuration containing 'gpgcheck=0' and set the value to '1'.

custom_item_1021.description: GEN008800 - The package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of packages during install.

custom_item_1022.description: GEN008800 - The package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of packages during install - '/etc/yum.repos.d/*'
custom_item_1022.info: To prevent the installation of software from unauthorized sources, the system package management tool must use cryptographic algorithms to verify the packages are authentic.
custom_item_1022.solution: Edit the YUM configuration containing 'gpgcheck=0' and set the value to '1'.

custom_item_1023.description: GEN008820 - The system package management tool must not automatically obtain updates.
custom_item_1023.info: System package management tools can obtain a list of updates and patches from a package repository and make this information available to the SA for review and action. Using a package repository outside of the organization's control presents a risk of malicious packages being introduced.
custom_item_1023.solution:
Disable the yum service.
# chkconfig yum-updatesd off ; service yum-updatesd stop

custom_item_1024.description: GEN001140 - System files and directories must not have uneven access permissions - '/etc/*'
custom_item_1024.info: Discretionary access control is undermined if users, other than a file owner, have greater access permissions to system files and directories than the owner.
custom_item_1024.solution: Change the mode of files with uneven permissions so owners do not have less permission than group or world users.

custom_item_1031.solution:

custom_item_1032.info: Restricting permission on daemons will protect them from unauthorized modification and possible system compromise.
custom_item_1032.solution:

custom_item_1033.description: GEN001200 - All system command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive - '/etc/*'
custom_item_1033.info: Restricting permissions will protect system command files from unauthorized modification. System command files include files present in directories used by the operating system for storing default system executables and files present in directories included in the system's default executable search paths.
custom_item_1033.solution:
Change the mode for system command files to 0755 or less permissive taking into account necessary GIUD and SUID bits.

Procedure:
# chmod go-w

custom_item_1060.description: GEN001240 - System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group - '/usr/sbin/*'
custom_item_1060.info: Restricting permissions will protect the files from unauthorized modification.
custom_item_1060.solution:
Change the group-owner of system files to a system group.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /path/to/system/file

(System groups other than root may be used.)

custom_item_1061.description: GEN001260 - System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive - '/var/log/*'
custom_item_1061.info: If the system log files are not protected, unauthorized users could change the logged data, eliminating its forensic value.
custom_item_1061.solution:
Change the mode of the system log file(s) to 0640 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod 0640 /path/to/system-log-file

Note: Do not confuse system log files with audit logs.

custom_item_1064.description: GEN001270 - All system log files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_1064.info: If the system log files are not protected, unauthorized users could change the logged data, eliminating its forensic value.  Authorized software may be given log file access through the use of extended ACLs when needed and configured to provide the least privileges required.
custom_item_1064.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.

Procedure:
# setfacl --remove-all [file with extended ACL]

custom_item_1075.description: GEN001580 - All run control scripts must have mode 0755 or less permissive - '/etc/init.d/*'
custom_item_1075.info: If the startup files are writable by other users, they could modify the startup files to insert malicious commands into the startup files.
custom_item_1075.solution:
Ensure all system startup files have mode 0755 or less permissive. Examine the 'rc' files, and all files in the rc1.d (rc2.d, and so on) directories, and in the /etc/init.d directory to ensure they are not world-writable. If they are world-writable, use the chmod command to correct the vulnerability and research why they are world-writable.

Procedure:
# chmod 755

custom_item_1084.description: GEN001605 - Run control scripts library search paths must contain only authorized paths - '/etc/init.d/*'
custom_item_1084.info: The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_1084.solution: Edit the run control script and remove the relative path entries from the library search path variables that are not documented with the ISSO.  Edit the run control script and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_1102.description: GEN004360 - The alias file must be owned by root - '/etc/aliases'
custom_item_1102.info: If the alias file is not owned by root, an unauthorized user may modify the file adding aliases to run malicious code or redirect e-mail.
custom_item_1102.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/aliases file to root.

Procedure:
for sendmail:
# chown root /etc/aliases
# chown root /etc/aliases.db

for postfix
# chown root /etc/postfix/aliases
# chown root /etc/postfix/aliases.db

custom_item_1106.description: GEN004370 - The aliases file must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or system - '/etc/aliases'
custom_item_1106.info: If the alias file is not group-owned by root or a system group, an unauthorized user may modify the file adding aliases to run malicious code or redirect e-mail.
custom_item_1106.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/aliases file.

Procedure:
for sendmail:
# chgrp root /etc/aliases
# chgrp smmsp /etc/aliases.db

The aliases.db file must be owned by the same system group as sendmail, which is smmsp by default.

for postfix
# chgrp root /etc/postfix/aliases
# chgrp root /etc/postfix/aliases.db

custom_item_1107.description: GEN004370 - The aliases file must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or system - '/etc/aliases.db'
custom_item_1107.info: If the alias file is not group-owned by root or a system group, an unauthorized user may modify the file adding aliases to run malicious code or redirect e-mail.
custom_item_1107.solution:
Change the group-owner of the /etc/aliases file.

Procedure:
for sendmail:
# chgrp root /etc/aliases
# chgrp smmsp /etc/aliases.db

The aliases.db file must be owned by the same system group as sendmail, which is smmsp by default.

for postfix
# chgrp root /etc/postfix/aliases
# chgrp root /etc/postfix/aliases.db

custom_item_1111.description: GEN004710 - Mail relaying must be restricted - '/etc/mail/sendmail.cf DaemonPortOptions'
custom_item_1111.info: If unrestricted mail relaying is permitted, unauthorized senders could use this host as a mail relay for the purpose of sending SPAM or other unauthorized activity.
custom_item_1111.solution:
If the system uses sendmail, edit the sendmail.mc file and remove the 'promiscuous_relay' configuration. Rebuild the sendmail.cf file from the modified sendmail.mc and restart the service. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add one or more DaemonPortOptions lines referencing system loopback addresses (such as 'O DaemonPortOptions=Addr=127.0.0.1,Port=smtp,Name=MTA') and remove lines containing non-loopback addresses. Restart the service.

If the system uses Postfix, edit the main.cf file and add or edit the 'smtpd_client_restrictions' line to have contents 'permit_mynetworks, reject' or a similarly restrictive rule. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add or edit the 'inet_interfaces' line to have contents 'loopback-only' or a set of loopback addresses for the system. Restart the service.

If the system is using other SMTP software, consult the software's documentation for procedures to restrict mail relaying.

custom_item_1119.description: Wireless network adapters must be disabled
custom_item_1119.info:
The use of wireless networking can introduce many different attack vectors into the organization's network. Common attack vectors such as malicious association and ad hoc networks will allow an attacker to spoof a wireless access point (AP), allowing validated systems to connect to the malicious AP and enabling the attacker to monitor and record network traffic. These malicious APs can also serve to create a man-in-the-middle attack or be used to create a denial of service to valid network resources.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_1119.solution: Configure the system to disable all wireless network interfaces.
